text: LONDON - Grief turned to anger as firefighters continued to battle one of London’s biggest fire disasters in recent memory and leaders faced questions about possible fire safety violations.Police say at least 12 people were killed as a rapidly-moving blaze raced through a 24-story apartment building in West London in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, trapping residents.The death toll was expected to rise as firefighters went floor by floor, dousing the remaining flames and searching for survivors and victims in the high-rise.Grenfell Tower contained an estimated 120 apartments and was home to as many as 600 people. The building is in an ethnically diverse, densely populated West London’s North Kensington area. Among those missing on Wednesday were a number of children.Witnesses said they heard screams for help as the fire stormed through the floors, trapping residents who could be seen from windows flashing their cell phone lights in hopes of being rescued. Witnesses said some residents held small children from windows while other people jumped from the lower stories of the building.?Watch video from the scene:Sorry, but your browser cannot support embedded video of this type, you can download this video to view it offline.Why did fire spread so quickly?

Turkey's former army chief was arrested on Friday over an alleged plot to topple the government of Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.General Ilker Basbug's lawyer said authorities have jailed his client, who is accused of leading a terrorist organization.A Turkish prosecutor called for the general to be taken into custody on Thursday after he was named as a suspect in an alleged Internet campaign aimed at destabilizing Erdogan's Islamic-based government.Turkish media reports said earlier this week that Basbug was called to answer questions in connection with the trial of current and former officers linked to the so-called secularist network, Ergenekon.Turkish authorities have detained more than 300 people including journalists, academics and politicians as part of a wide-reaching investigation into Ergenekon.The case has highlighted international concerns about press freedom in Turkey. Thursday, journalists Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik were among 13 defendants who appeared in court to begin their defense case against charges they are linked to Ergenekon.

A former North Korean spy has met with family members of a Japanese woman who was apparently abducted by the North's agents. Kim Hyun-hee - once sentenced to death for blowing up an airliner - says she may have information about the Japanese woman's fate.Former North Korean spy Kim Hyun-hee wiped tears from her eyes, Wednesday, as she spoke to the brother and son of a Japanese woman who disappeared decades ago.Kim told the relatives not to give up hope and that they will see the woman again. Kim Hyun-hee has not appeared in such a high-profile way since 1991 - when she spoke to the South Korean public about an act of terrorism she was convicted of committing, four years earlier. Kim says she placed a bomb on a Korean Airlines flight that exploded in midair, killing all 115 people on board. For that crime, she was sentenced to die, then given a South Korean presidential pardon.To fulfill her mission, Kim posed with another North Korean agent as a married Japanese couple. She says was able to speak and act as a Japanese person because she was taught for two years by Yaeko Taguchi - the woman whose family says she was abducted to North Korea in 1978.Wednesday's emotional meeting between Kim and two of Taguchi's male family members took place in Busan.

NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has pledged that "the door is open" for Georgia to join the alliance, but he also warned that Georgia and Turkey were not close to being a close partner.Stoltenberg told RIA Novosti that it was "inevitable" that Georgia join NATO, since both it and Turkey are NATO members."I am confident that the doors are open and we are moving in that direction," Stoltenberg said in an interview with RIA Novosti TV on Tuesday."The relationship is in such a good position that we must not wait for Georgia and Turkey. Let them be ready, they will be ready."

Should Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein recuse himself from overseeing the Robert Mueller investigation? This question may become more and more relevant to the country during the remainder of the Trump presidency. The decision would be driven by a desire on the part of Democrats to maintain control over the legislative branch, while making sure they retain control over the administration.Trump’s current Deputy Attorney General Matt Whitaker has already been critical of Mueller’s investigation and has accused Rosenstein of leaking the contents of the special counsel’s team memos. There has also been speculation that Mueller’s findings could damage Trump’s political prospects for reelection, and if he decides that he is not going to get to the bottom of the truth from the Special Counsel, he will fire Rosenstein and start his own investigation, similar to the way George W. Bush used to operate when he felt he was not getting the results he wanted.If the Department of Justice (DOJ) decides that it is a question of whether Rosenstein should step away from overseeing the Mueller investigation, or more importantly, whether the President should allow a third person into the investigation, this could lead to a major political showdown.In fact, if there were a third person in charge, it would be far more difficult for the White House to claim that it has no connection to the investigation, which is currently going on inside the White House. Even if the President decides that he has the right person in charge and has no intention of giving up his investigation, he would have to answer to the question of if he should pardon or pardon Mueller’s team of investigators. This would open up a new series of scandals if the President decides to pardon or pardon them before he is forced to fire the investigator or if Mueller’s team of investigators or prosecutors, as a whole, have become so enraged and frustrated that they retaliate by finding a way to go on national TV and claim that the President or the administration has interfered with the investigation.The question of whether or not Rosenstein should step away from oversight of the Mueller investigation is not just a political issue. This issue, and the possible ramifications, should be of utmost concern to the entire country.One of the most interesting questions facing the country, not just Democrats, is if President Trump had a collusion or obstruction of justice. We know that President Trump has denied allegations of having collusion, but it may not be as simple as that.

The White House, despite President Joe Biden's commitment to the country, has shown no signs of giving up on it.The White House is not giving up on Afghanistan, as President Biden said he had done, but not necessarily for the reason that he said he would at the beginning of his administration.During a press conference Friday, White House chief of staff Ron Klain said that despite the withdrawal of all American troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11, "we are continuing to focus our efforts on Afghanistan as the country and its people begin to rebuild and take advantage of the opportunities it presents," according to an ABC News report.President Biden has repeatedly said that the Taliban should not be allowed to become a legitimate government.However, the Biden administration has been far more diplomatic than President Trump.During the second presidential debate in September, Trump made the comments that led to the withdrawal of the last troops."Taliban can never be government in Afghanistan," Trump said. "They don't have the power."However, the Trump administration is now using the Taliban to justify its withdrawal.The Associated Press reports that Secretary of State Antony Blinken gave an interview to ABC News on Tuesday that confirmed the United States' intentions to leave Afghanistan "in the coming weeks."

The Bush administration says it is not contemplating curtailing the current surge of U.S. forces in Iraq, as it prepares its first report on the surge due this week to an increasingly skeptical Congress. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.Both here and at the White House, officials steered reporters away from a New York Times story that says senior officials are discussing changing the Iraq strategy President Bush announced in January. White House spokesman Tony Snow put it this way."There is no intensifying discussion about reducing troops," said Tony Snow.At the Pentagon, spokesman Bryan Whitman acknowledged that Defense Secretary Robert Gates postponed a trip to Latin America in order to participate in policy meetings on Iraq this week. He said discussions are going on about what he called "the way ahead" in Iraq. And he reported that Secretary Gates participated in a national security team meeting early Monday morning, after meeting with the commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, Admiral William Fallon.But Whitman also noted that the latest security operation in Iraq is just three weeks old, and began as soon as all the extra forces President Bush ordered to Iraq had arrived."What this department is focused on is implementing the full capabilities that the surge forces are giving the commanders on the ground," said Bryan Whitman.Whitman dismissed comments by a growing number of Republican members of Congress, who have said the new Iraq strategy is not working and needs to be changed."None of those people seem to be our military commanders on the ground," he said.

PeopleAnadolu AgencyANKARA – At least 34 people were killed when two bombs exploded in the Turkish capital of Ankara. In total, at least 60 people were wounded.The first blast hit a popular place for tourists in the city of Ataturk. The second blast hit a crowd gathering at a football stadium, injuring at least five others.The bombings occurred as Turkey's government was making an attempt to boost business and social ties following a failed coup attempt.After the deadly bombing, Turkey's president Recep Tayyip Erdogan addressed the nation, ordering security forces to take action."The first thing is security of the capital," Erdogan said. "So we must not allow anyone to put Turkey in a risky situation."Turkey has been under a state of emergency since a failed coup attempt on July 15, with military leaders and their families being held in extra-judicial detention.In the aftermath of the failed coup, Erdogan is working to boost economic growth and has also pledged to implement a series of social reforms that would make Turkey more attractive to investors.Turkey has been under a state of emergency since a failed coup attempt on July 15, with military leaders and their families being held in extra-judicial detention.More than 677 people were arrested in the aftermath of the coup attempt, according to a state-run tally. The government says some of those detained are no longer involved in the coup.More than 10,000 people have been sacked from their jobs in the government, according to government figures.Turkey faces international criticism over the detention and prosecution of people suspected of being members of a terror group.In July, more than 200 people were killed when a soldier attempted to overthrow Erdogan during a ceremony marking the country's Armed Forces Day.

Bill Cosby’s world is finally being set in stone.The actor is now opening the doors to the public on his private life, for the first time since 2015 when he was first charged and then acquitted by a Pennsylvania jury.The show will be a benefit for his foundation, the Bill Cosby Foundation.According to the Hollywood Reporter, Cosby will be telling stories at the Philadelphia Improv on Saturday night.Cosby says he doesn’t know how much he will tell yet but that he will be “very, very emotional.”The actor will tell a variety of stories in hopes that some will be able to help his foundation “fight and protect and advance men and women, who are suffering in silence because of their pain, because they are afraid of speaking out.”Cosby says he is hopeful that the support will go beyond the community of women who were affected by his misconduct. He is also hopeful that those who are impacted by the criminal cases will seek the support of their victims.“I know that my words are important but I also know that my words may go unheeded or disregarded,” Cosby said. “If my words can make a difference in a single woman’s heart, then I know I have done my job.”Cosby has continued his public advocacy, using social media platforms to push back on the #MeToo movement, which was sparked when comedian Bill Cosby was arrested.This will be the first time Cosby has spoken since his first day in prison when he was released on a $1 million bond on April 26.

The family of Basuki Tjahaya Purnama and his lawyers on Tuesday announced the recently defeated governor of Jakarta better known as "Ahok" had revoked the decision to appeal a two-year sentence for blasphemy handed down by the North Jakarta District Court.Ahok's wife, Veronica Tan, delivered the notice to the court Monday. She did not comment on the decision, which was filed less than an hour after Purnama's legal team filed paperwork for the appeal, according to local media.On Tuesday, she cried as she read a statement written by her husband."I know it's not easy for you to accept this fact, much less me," she said at a news conference, quoting her husband. "But I have learned to forgive and accept all this, for the good of the nation and the state."

The U.S. government on Thursday marked International Women's Day by recognizing 10 women who are fighting for human rights and equality. Presenting this year's International Women of Courage awards, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said championing women's equality is not only the right thing to do, it is the smart thing to do."Improving the lives of women improves the lives of their families, strengthens their communities and does create more opportunities for economic growth and prosperity," she said. "We know that investing in women's employment, health and education levels leads to a greater economic growth across a broad spectrum.?

A building collapsed in a southern city of South Korea on Thursday, killing at least nine people and leaving dozens of residents homeless. The country’s fire and rescue agency confirmed the death toll to news agency Yonhap News.The cause of the collapse in the eastern city of Uijeongbu is not known, but it is believed to be linked to a collapsed ceiling. The building, a condominium, was built in 2006.Uijeongbu's fire department said nine people were dead and 12 seriously injured, with the city saying it would start a thorough rescue operation from Friday morning.The fire department said a dozen people have been sent to hospitals.The city is a popular holiday destination as well as home to some of South Korea's largest businesses, including Samsung Electronics.The Uijeongbu district has long suffered from poor maintenance, and in the latest collapse the city's mayor had said the building's structural design was "irregular and not up to scratch".

An attack on a vehicle that was carrying Somali officials, including a minister of agriculture, and a local mayor has left two soldiers dead as the militants drove through an Ethiopian military base in the city of Mogadishu today, according to witnesses.The Ethiopian military, which has been deployed along Mogadishu's outskirts since a coup in the city five years ago, were not immediately in contact with the militants. The attack took place at a time when Ethiopian Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn and a delegation of Somali officials are visiting Addis Ababa.The two civilians were killed when the militants opened fire on their convoy, a Somali government official, who requested anonymity, told the Associated Press.

BERLIN - An old-time propeller plane crashed near-vertically at high speed into a Swiss mountain, killing all 20 people on board, police said Sunday. The Junkers Ju-52 plane, operated by the Swiss company Ju-Air, went down Saturday on the Piz Segnas mountain above the Alpine resort of Flims, striking the mountain's western flank about 2,540 meters (8,330 feet) above sea level. The mountainous area in southeastern Switzerland is popular with hikers and skiers and includes a glacier. Police said Sunday they have now determined that all 20 people on board the plane, including its three crew members, died. Eleven men and nine women between the ages of 42 and 84 were killed. Most of the victims were Swiss but they also included a couple and their son from Austria. Photos released by Graubuenden canton (state) police showed the crumpled wreckage of the plane lying on the mountain, with only the upside-down tail more or less intact. Police said they are not aware of any distress call from the aircraft before it crashed. Daniel Knecht of the Swiss Transportation Safety Investigation Board said the plane appears to have hit the ground near-vertically and at high speed.

With IraqOn Sept. 6, 2014, when the Iraqi government announced that a military offensive against Kurdish militants, backed by Turkey, was imminent, the immediate response from the Kurds was, “No, not unless you give us more autonomy.”Now, according to sources in Erbil and Baghdad, the two parties are working on an accord that will allow the Kurds a little more power.Sources say that they are trying to avoid a military strike against the Kurds, because they fear that a U.S.-led coalition would attack their civilian population.But they are also working on a deal to allow for the deployment of an additional 200,000 Iraqi troops to clear disputed areas of northern and southern Iraq that were occupied by the Kurds.The Kurdish parties are also expected to demand recognition by the Iraqi parliament of their political ambitions, especially the ability to set up a political cabinet without the need for a majority in parliament.Kurdish politicians say that they are waiting for the Iraqi government to send their delegation to the Kurdistan Region to see how many seats the Kurdish delegation may request for a parliamentary majority. The Kurdish delegation may be able to force the Iraqi government into a coalition with them, since parliamentarians are required to be Kurdish themselves.According to the sources, in order to break their political impasse, the Iraqi government has given the Kurds a promise that the Kurdish leadership will be free to set up a security force and police force.The leaders of the Kurdish political parties have been invited to come to Baghdad and discuss with the prime minister and other senior government officials the terms of the compromise reached between the Kurds and the Iraqi government, which is said to include the creation of an autonomous police force that is responsible for security along the northern and southern Iraq borders.A Kurdish political source told Kurdistan24.net that he expected a deal to be reached soon, as the next elections are set to take place in April 2016. However, the Kurdish leaders are expected to hold back until they are sure of the Iraqi government’s support to take them on.If Baghdad’s backing for the Kurds comes into question, it is believed that the Iraqi military could launch a military operation against them, similar to how the U.S. carried out a crackdown against the Kurdistan Regional Government in 2003.

in DetroitDETROIT (AP) — The prosecution and defense for the man charged in the deaths of two men in Detroit are expected to wrap up their arguments in his racketeering trial on Wednesday.The six-week trial opened in September. It focuses on the case of Andre Jones, charged in 2018 with the 2017 murders of 27-year-old Andre Bledsoe and 23-year-old David "DJ" Bell. The killings were the first murders of the year in Detroit.Jones, 25, allegedly lured the two victims with lies about a drug deal before killing them. But prosecutors allege he orchestrated the killings out of greed and hatred for police and those who worked to curb violent crime.The killings took place during a decade of record homicides in Detroit that have been largely blamed on police. More officers have been killed and more residents shot in Detroit since the turn of the century.Jones' defense team has argued that prosecutors ignored many factors before charging Jones.According to witnesses during the trial, Jones and others plotted to murder the two men for months. After the deaths, police questioned Bledsoe's mother. Police were later involved in an altercation with Jones and several other people, but the shooting was unrelated to the killings.The shooting has become a flashpoint in the Black Lives Matter movement. Some prosecutors say the killing could have been prevented with other police techniques to keep people in check. A prosecutor has said the killing was pre-planned.The trial was initially scheduled to be delayed after a juror was exposed to the coronavirus. However, the judge presiding over the trial allowed the jury to continue on Tuesday, the last day of testimony.A prosecutor said the juror and 12 other people were safe from contracting the virus. The 12 were sequestered in a hotel. They will be sent to a facility on Thursday to begin serving as jurors, and possibly begin the trial on Friday.The defense is expected to call another lawyer to replace the first trial-opening juror. The defense will likely ask for a mistrial or to dismiss the case outright.The prosecution will appeal the judge's ruling on the voir dire — which means the jury selection process — and ask to see the juror who originally was sequestered, Judge Steven Rhodes.© 2020 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

ATHENS - Europe's refugee crisis is posing risks for the Greek economy and the country needs substantial help to deal with the migratory flows, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said on Thursday."The refugee crisis creates significant problems for the Greek economy and growth," OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria told reporters after meeting Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Athens."Greece needs to receive substantial support to deal with this new challenge. No single country can address this challenge on its own," he said in comments translated into Greek.Gurria projected zero growth for the Greek economy this year and a 1.9 to 2 percent GDP increase in 2017.

, Says CEO in Letter to StaffThis story has been updated.Luxury watchmaker Swatch Group, maker of the Swatch Watch, the Omega Seamaster, and other fine brands, is preparing to sell parts of its watchmaking division.In a letter to staff on July 31, Richard Lai, Swatch’s CEO, said that the company has made the difficult decision to sell a portion of its watchmaking business and that the move would help ensure the company’s financial strength.According to Lai, the timing of the decision is important because of recent “market uncertainty” surrounding watches.The decision to sell the watchmaking business is a necessary one, Lai said, and will allow Swatch to invest more heavily in the core technology of the watches it produces.In other news on Monday, July 27, Lai said that during the company’s first quarter earnings call, he told staff that the company had invested $8.5 million into developing its new watchOS operating system. Lai went on to say that the investment, which was included in the company’s earnings report for the first quarter of the year, would help ensure that the company’s future would not be at risk in the event of another financial crisis.Read more from the Wall Street Journal in the link above.FTC: We use income earning auto affiliate links. Thousands of opposition supporters rallied in Taiwan today to protest President Chen Shui-bian's independence-leaning policies which are increasingly provoking China. Protestors are concerned Mr. Chen is spending more time stirring up trouble with China than solving problems at home.Tens of thousands of demonstrators chanted slogans in Taipei Sunday criticizing President Chen Shui-bian recent moves that have antagonized China.In the last several months, Mr. Chen has sparked tensions with Beijing when he suspended a commission responsible for reunification with China. He also scrapped reunification guidelines and proposed amending the constitution to change the island's name from "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."China sees these actions as moving dangerously close to Taiwan formally declaring independence - something Beijing has vowed to stop by force if necessary. While the democratic island has been self-ruled since 1949 - the communist mainland considers it a renegade province.China's opposition Kuomintang organized Sunday's rally, calling on the Chen government to stop provoking China and focus on domestic issues.Kuomintang chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, spoke to crowds of supporters.Ma says there are many problems Taiwan needs to address - including corruption and the economy. He says if Taiwan gets its priorities wrong there will be a huge price to pay.Ma, who is the mayor of Taipei and considered a presidential favorite in Taiwan's 2008 elections, will be in the United States this week.He is to discuss a stalled U.S. weapons sale.

Israeli authorities have approved 200 new homes in a Jewish area of East Jerusalem, a move sure to anger Palestinians as tensions between the two sides continue to grow.A government spokeswoman said officials approved the houses Wednesday for the Ramot area on the northern edge of Jerusalem.There was no immediate comment from Palestinian officials. But U.S. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said the United States was deeply concerned. She said new Jewish settlement construction could worsen a difficult situation and would not contribute to efforts to reduce tensions.Psaki also condemned an arson attack on a mosque in the West Bank on Wednesday, apparently carried out by Israeli extremists. She said hateful actions against a place of worship are never justified.Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas during a visit to Jordan on Thursday.Much of the recent violence in Israel has stemmed from the dispute over the Temple Mount, a holy site that Muslims call the al-Aqsa mosque. It is revered by Muslims and Jews.The long-simmering dispute over the site worsened this month when Israeli police shot dead a Palestinian gunman who had seriously wounded a U.S.-born rabbi. The rabbi had been part of a conference on expanding the rights of Jews to worship at the site.Also Wednesday, Israel's foreign ministry said it had no intention of cooperating with a U.N.

KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) — Two climbers are dead and another is missing in Nepal after a separate incident at the highest and most dangerous mountain peak in the world, the state tourism ministry said Sunday.A statement from the ministry said at least one climber died Saturday at the 8,850-meter (29,310-foot) Manang Boche (Eagle Mount) on the west side of Nepal’s highest peak.It said an Indian mountaineer and an Italian climber were also killed after they fell ill at the peak, with their bodies found at the peak Sunday.The ministry said the climbers died after suffering severe altitude sickness and couldn’t be rescued. The first climber, an Italian, had reached the peak on Sunday, and the second Italian was on Monday, according to the statement.The Manang Boche summit has recorded at least 19 deaths in the last century. One climber died at the peak in 2017 in another accident.A man in his 30s died last June after setting off an explosives-laden rope at the base of the peak, an incident that earned Nepal’s attention because of the high stakes involved.

Ethiopia's football team has reached the group stage of the 2014 World Cup qualifiers with a comfortable victory over neighboring Somalia. But, for the thousands of Somalis packed into a corner of Addis Ababa stadium, a 5-0 drubbing felt like a victory.As Somalia's fans trooped out of the stands following Wednesday's game, you might have thought they had won. Twenty-five-year-old Mohamed Hussein, a Somali refugee from Mogadishu, was ecstatic.?I'm so happy, I want to thank the players, and I want to thank the people of Somalia today who stay in Addis Ababa who support our team," said Hussein.A valiant Somali side held Ethiopia to a scoreless draw in the first leg of this home and away match, held Saturday in Djibouti. In this return leg in Addis Ababa, the Ocean Stars trailed by only 1-0 at the one hour mark, before the superior Ethiopian side unleashed a torrent of goals.The team for war-torn Somalia faces huge disadvantages in international competition, among them the lack of a home field. Mogadishu Stadium has not been used for sporting events in recent years. Instead, it was used by Islamist militant group al-Shabab for floggings and executions.Somali refugee Hamdi Wardhere called the final score ?great? considering the difficulties his country faces."I'm very delighted how I see my team and how they played, so I'm very happy really," said Wardhere.

President Edgar Chagwa Lungu's main political challenger is charged with treason and will appear before the chief magistrate on Thursday.The charge against Musokotwani Kambwili (52) is a result of an interview that he gave in which he said that Chagwa Lungu was planning to use police to remove him from the presidency.Kambwili, who is running for the presidency in September, is the leading opposition party candidate in the upcoming elections.The police arrested Kambwili in February over a series of comments he made against Chagwa Lungu.He was detained in Luapula and then on April 12 he was charged with "waging war," a crime under Zambia's criminal code.In the interview, Kambwili said "it's the end" for President Edgar Chagwa Lungu. He claimed that the President was not ready to step down and "in fact this is actually planned to have us killed, which is a big thing".At the time, police arrested Kambwili as he was en route to attend the funeral of a political aide who died that day.He was charged two weeks later and later convicted after appearing before the courts.Kambwili was found not guilty of a treason charge by the magistrate.

Somalia's interim Prime Minister Ali Mohamed Gedi says his secular government troops and their Ethiopian allies are firmly in control of the capital, Mogadishu, one day after the once-powerful Islamists hastily abandoned the city. VOA Correspondent Alisha Ryu has details from our East Africa Bureau in Nairobi.In a telephone interview with VOA shortly before he entered the capital, Prime Minister Gedi says Somali government troops are now headquartered in the former U.S. Embassy compound in western Mogadishu and assessing the security situation.The interim leader acknowledges that the first priority for his government is to restore stability in the capital. He says he has been given assurances by clan elders in Mogadishu that they would switch support of the Islamists to the interim government and help disarm and re-train hundreds of Islamist militiamen, who found themselves without a job Thursday after the sudden collapse of the Islamist movement."They are ready to hand over weapons to the government and also the militias to be trained in camps. So, this is a victory for the Somali people in the country and in particular, the capital city of Mogadishu," he said.Many Islamist fighters shed their uniforms and sought advice from clan leaders about what to do next.

A leader at one of Virginia's largest mosques has resigned after the imam there made comments in support of female genital mutilation.Imam Johari Abdul-Malik, who was director of outreach at the Dar Al-Hijrah mosque in Falls Church, posted his resignation Friday on his website.Abdul-Malik says he's leaving after "many reprehensible statements" by Dar Al-Hijrah's senior imam, Shaker Elsayed, including his recent comments on genital mutilation.In a recorded lecture, Elsayed described the practice as a way to avoid "hyper-sexuality" and "the honorable thing to do if needed."Dar Al-Hijrah's board denounced Elsayed's comments Monday. Two days later, it placed him on administrative leave.FILE - Imam Shaker Elsayed delivers the sermon at prayers services at the Dar al-Hijra mosque in Falls Church, Va., June 15, 2005.In the lecture, Elsayed says that the practice, also known as female circumcision, has received a bad name because poorly trained surgeons are too aggressive in the procedure. He said the surgery is properly carried out with a minimalist approach "so that she is not hyper-sexually active. This is the purpose."Elsayed later issued a clarification through the mosque's website saying that "Islam would never support anything that harms anybody's well-being" and that he should have avoided his comments on hyper-sexuality."I hereby take it back. And I do apologize to all those who are offended by it," Elsayed wrote.Abdul-Malik says in his resignation that the board's actions against Elsayed are insufficient."Ultimately, The Board of Dar Al-Hijrah Islamic Center is responsible for the direction of the community and its leadership.

North Korea has fired another ballistic missile, days after the United States imposed new sanctions on the reclusive state.South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said the missile flew 800 kilometers before crashing off the North's eastern coast early Friday. The South said it tracked the projectile and was monitoring the situation.A U.S. defense official says the U.S. tracked the launch of two ballistic missiles from North Korea. The official said neither was assessed to be a threat to the U.S. or its allies, and noted that the launches are a violation of multiple U.N. Security Council resolutions.President Barack Obama signed an executive order imposing new sanctions Wednesday in response to the authoritarian regime's latest nuclear and ballistic missile tests.Earlier this week, Pyongyang's state media said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had ordered tests of a nuclear warhead and ballistic missiles capable of carrying warheads.Military tensions have been soaring on the divided Korean Peninsula since the North carried out its fourth nuclear test on January 6, followed a month later by a long-range rocket launch that was widely seen as a disguised ballistic missile test.The North says it needs nuclear weapons to cope with what it calls U.S. military threats.After the latest firing, the United States called on North Korea to refrain from actions that raise tensions in the region.

New warnings of famine and food shortages have been sounded for parts of the Horn of Africa.The Famine Early Warning Systems Network says more than one-million people in south and southeast Ethiopia face "extreme food insecurity" due to the failure of normal late-year rains.The U.S.-funded group says pre-famine conditions have emerged in several districts, including Afder, Liban and Gode).The group says two million people need humanitarian aid in Somalia, mostly in the south, where the poor rainfall has led to widespread crop failure.

New Zealand police said there were multiple fatalities after a mass shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, a city of about 375,000 located on the nation’s South Island.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the shootings have led to “one of New Zealand’s darkest days.”What is the history of Christchurch, New Zealand?The planned settlement of Christchurch was founded in 1850 by a company financed by the Church of England.?4,545,627, as of July 2018, according to the CIA: The World Factbook.The estimated number of guns (both licit and illicit) held by civilians in New Zealand was estimated to be more than 1.2 million in 2017, according to GunPolicy.org.New Zealand has had few mass shooting deaths. One of the deadliest cases involved David Gray who in November 1990 went on a shooting spree in the small town of Aramoana, located about 360 kilometers south of Christchurch.

over Election Inflammatory RemarksCongressional Democrats announced Saturday they are moving closer to impeaching Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross over their controversial statements about voter fraud at the heart of the Trump legal challenge to the results of the presidential election.The House Judiciary Committee voted 20-14 to hold Barr and Ross in contempt of Congress for refusing to hand over the full transcript of their remarks in which they said voter fraud caused President Donald Trump's election loss to Joe Biden."To the extent that Secretary Ross did not produce the full transcript of his comments, in part or in whole, on the evening of November 9, 2019, and to the extent he failed to make the full transcript of a portion of such comments available to this Committee, the full Committee is prepared to hold Secretary Ross and Attorney General Barr in contempt," Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) said during the committee vote, according to the Hill.Rep. Jim McGovern (D-MA), the committee's chair, said his panel is ready to proceed with an impeachment investigation into Barr and Ross. "At the request of the House Judiciary Committee, this afternoon, my committee voted to initiate proceedings for contempt of Congress against Secretary Barr and Attorney General Ross," McGovern said in a statement. "I have received the subpoena and it shall be forwarded to the relevant offices. This is only the first step, though, and I am confident that it will be followed by other steps in the course of our oversight responsibilities."Ross' lawyers have filed a motion to dismiss the House Judiciary Committee's efforts in a bid to avoid contempt proceedings. The Justice Department argues Ross was entitled to make his comments privately, and the transcript should be available to the public.House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) also called on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) to force a vote to impeach the secretaries, but Pelosi said she wanted a full and transparent investigation first and wanted the full transcript of the remarks produced to Congress."This is so clear to me," Pelosi said Saturday. "These folks can't be trusted to speak for themselves. Let's do the investigation that we have to do and let's have an understanding of what the secretary said and not just what it looks like from his lawyers."

Chad's Constituent Assembly unanimously approved a new constitution Thursday, giving the incumbent president broad new powers to manage his nation.The new text adds a new presidential mandate of up to two-and-a-half years, with a maximum six-year term. It also makes a presidential election every five years and grants greater powers to the prime minister.The changes were made in the face of widespread unrest sparked in March 2014 by the government's attempts to restrict protests and prevent a coup in northern Chad.The text had already been approved by parliament in an initial stage in October 2014.Chad is currently ruled by an interim government, appointed by a general elected in May to replace an elected president.Thursday's vote was to approve a new Constitution for the country, whose name is based on that of the Chad Republic.The new document, which still needs to be approved by the Constitutional Court before becoming law, also requires approval from the Chadian Senate before it can take effect, a step that has been blocked by the opposition.Chad's Constitutional Court will have to approve the new constitution.

The U.S. space agency NASA has released the first three dimensional pictures of the sun. It says the new view will greatly help scientists understand solar storms that can disrupt communications and power systems on Earth. VOA's David McAlary reports.The new 3-D images came from twin NASA spacecraft named STEREO, launched last October. They are orbiting the sun, one slightly ahead of Earth and the other slightly behind, gradually separating from each other until they are 500,000 kilometers apart. The separation provides a three dimensional view of the sun, just as the offset in our eyes gives us depth perception.Until the advent of this identical pair of observatories, images from Earth telescopes or orbiting solar telescopes were two dimensional. NASA solar scientist Madhulika Guhathakurta says the three dimensional images will help scientists determine where matter and energy flow in the sun's atmosphere much more precisely."We have to move away from the traditional sun-Earth line to view the sun from around, from over the poles, from under the poles to really get a deeper understanding of what is inside the sun, what is coming out of its surface, how is it affecting the entire solar system that we live in," said Madhulika Guhathakurta.The main STEREO project scientist, Michael Kaiser, says the satellites' depth perception will help improve space weather forecasts.Of particular concern are powerful eruptions of billions of tons of electrically charged gas that smash into Earth's magnetic field at millions of kilometers per hour.

Getachew Engida spoke in an interview Thursday about his work as deputy director general of the large U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, his views on the growth and development of societies around the world and his career path that lead him to UNESCO.“I wanted to do things that go beyond the financial and other profit goals,” Getachew said, “to explore causes that are not necessarily for profit-making but are good for the betterment of the society." He spoke with Alula Kebede, host of Cultural MosaicThe deputy director previously served for six years as comptroller of the Paris-based agency with oversight of a half-billion dollar annual budget.

WASHINGTON - The United States urged all Venezuelan political parties on Monday to follow up on the country's elections with a dialogue to deal with the country's economic and social challenges, saying Washington is ready to support such an effort.U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry congratulated Venezuelans on Sunday's legislative elections, in which the ruling Socialists lost their majority in the National Asseembly.The United States has long had an acrimonious relationship with Venezuela, which under President Nicolas Maduro and President Hugo Chavez before him has been a vocal critic of Washington.In a written statement, Kerry said the vote showed Venezuelans' "overwhelming desire" for a change in the direction of the country, and urged authorities "to continue to tabulate and publish voting results in a timely and transparent fashion."Sunday's victory for the opposition Democratic Unity coalition punished Maduro's government for deep economic and social crisis in the oil-producing country. It was the first time in 16 years that the "Chavismo" movement, named for former President Chavez, lost its majority in the 167-member assembly."

MANILA - The Philippines is one of the world’s most vulnerable countries when it comes to disasters and weather-related events. And this week it is hosting a three-day intensive seminar to help develop “climate leaders” who will be tasked to call attention to the impacts of climate change and what action can be taken.Climate reality From 1994 to 2013, the Philippines had 328 major weather events making it the worst-off country, according to data presented by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, now the chairman of the Washington-based Climate Reality Project. Second on the list was Bangladesh, with 228 events.Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore addresses participants during a three-day climate change training and workshop on how best to address the effects of global climate change on March 14, 2016 in suburban Pasay city, south of Manila, Philippines.Gore’s presentation in Manila made the connection between rising earth temperatures, powerful storms, extreme heat, more prolonged drought and their impact on food supplies, public health and political stability.“I am constantly challenged in my own heart to realize the magnitude of these biblical changes that are going on right now,” he said.“ And we are the people alive in this day and time that have a responsibility to recognize it and then to act.”

On July 19, Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced that same-sex marriages in Indonesia will be legal from December 13. The move was long overdue: in 2002, the Supreme Court ruled that same-sex unions were legal in Indonesia. But after the decision, several Indonesian organizations began an advocacy campaign, pushing for a repeal of the law.In recent months, the number of states that have allowed same-sex marriages have more than doubled. The most notable are: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Iowa, Oklahoma, and most recently Florida, which recently became the 11th U.S. state to permit same-sex unions.And now, in Indonesia, the Supreme Court has ruled that same-sex marriages are legal nationwide, but with many hurdles. As you'll see, it's not a simple change as many believe it will be. The Indonesian LGBTQ community is divided, with many hoping that the ruling will mean equal marriage rights for them and others in Indonesia. And it's all a matter of how that's applied:Homosexuality: "All people need to feel accepted by society."Transgender: "Transgender people are people of the opposite sex who need to change their gender for the right reasons."Discrimination: "Discrimination against anyone based on sexual orientation is legal."Homosexuality: "Homosexuality is a natural desire or sexual attraction; a human being cannot choose to be a homosexual."Transgender: "Transgender people are people who change their gender for the right reasons."Discrimination: "Discrimination against anyone based on their sexual orientation or gender identity is legal and is punishable by law."Heterosexuality: "Heterosexuality is a romantic attraction between a man and a woman, as well as a romantic attraction between a man and a woman."Discrimination: "Discrimination against anyone based on sexual orientation is allowed and is punishable by law."The Indonesian LGBTQ community, as well as activists working to expand rights for the community, is divided. And some hope that the ruling will mean equal rights, others believe the Indonesian government and courts have become so stacked in support of the Christian and conservative majority they are ignoring the rights of the country's LGBTQ community. In other words, the ruling is about as legal as it gets.

The Environmental Protection Agency announced on Friday the findings of its investigation into the use of plastics in the production of baby food. The agency reported that a number of baby food products sold in the U.S. contained non-recyclable single-use plastic straws and balls.The agency noted it would "provide additional guidance on how best to minimize the use of non-recyclable plastic straws and balls from infant formula products, particularly with respect to those found to contain non-recyclable straws and balls."It is, though, far from certain that there are no such products on the market and that the EPA will be able to do much about them. As the agency's director of outreach tells it, there aren't a whole lot of plastic options available in terms of recyclability.The Consumerist reported earlier this year that a few manufacturers had been sending back some of the plastic they'd produced for baby food in an attempt to "get around" the EPA's restrictions, which ban the use of single-use plastic bottles for food products.Some of the baby food manufacturers have also been offering reusable bottles, which they say can be made from recycled bottles. The issue is that these products are sold at a variety of price points, with some costing around $100.On top of that, some of the best-selling baby food brands are not even using 100% recycled bottles for infant formula, The Consumerist noted earlier this year.Even in some cases, which may be easily recyclable, there's still not necessarily a market for all of these products, consumer advocates say.Many of the companies that have stopped making plastic straws and balls for baby food say the straws and balls have helped improve their bottom line, as people use them on an ever-increasing basis to drink from their beverages.The Consumerist's sources say that the straws and balls, and other products that may not be 100% recycled, are still available to buy at supermarkets, but the bulk of the supply is in the hands of other companies, not baby food manufacturers."We can't buy all the plastic," one major baby food manufacturer said this summer. "It's a business decision. We're taking things apart and doing them in smaller batches to make them more accessible and affordable.

A Russian-born Ukrainian, Natalia Tymoshenko, is seeking a European Union member to help bring about the execution of her father, former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, accused of treason in the Ukraine.Tymoshenko was freed from prison on the condition that she sign the Russian confession of guilt for the murders but she rejected the offer.She has already been granted amnesty by Ukraine’s President Viktor Yanukovych.Ukrainian human rights groups say that the murder of Mykola Tymoshenko was committed with direct involvement of Yanukovich’s government and the two were in a state of war by then.A European court was also scheduled to hear the case of the Tymoshenko family, which could have significant international ramifications.It could also be significant for a Ukrainian case, since a judge in Germany is set to determine whether the Russian president has broken his silence on the Tymoshenko case by granting amnesty to Yulia Tymoshenko.

The Philippines and its allies have vowed not to let Chinese ships enter their waters, in a bid to prevent what the Chinese calls their'revenge' for a decades-old territorial dispute in the South China Sea.U.S. President Donald Trump said in August that if China's military "moves in any kind of aggressive way, they are going to get met with tremendous force."Trump told the Philippines to prepare for an "active" military response if the situation "continues to get worse."Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has also vowed to give a robust response to any Chinese aggression.However, some Filipinos are worried that there may be too many bad reactions for a country that is currently dealing with one of its worst political crises in years.The United States and China have been at loggerheads in Asia over territorial disputes in the South China Sea and Taiwan. Both sides claim the waters and islands.The Philippines has also found China constructing artificial islands in its territorial waters.Philippines National Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana said the United States had warned the Philippines of the dire consequences of its actions."The United States made it very clear that China has made it very clear that if it encroached further in the area it will be met with a more forceful response," Lorenzana told CNN."We heard from President Trump himself that if that doesn't happen, if the Philippines moves in that direction, then they are going to have to respond in kind," he said.But Lorenzana admitted that it was difficult to know when Duterte will make a public statement about his intentions."So far, we are going on what the president wants," he said, adding that a decision might not be made until the end of the week.The Philippine navy on Friday warned it will not allow China to build facilities on the disputed South China Sea rocks."Those activities violate our country's sovereign rights as guaranteed by international law," the navy said in a statement, the first public statement by Philippine officials on the maritime conflict."

Languageby John SmedleyJanuary 24, 2011[image by John Smedley]January 24, 2011The Daily Mail has an article today about two young South Africa-born women who are on a mission to bring hope to some of those who have faced starvation or forced marriages.

The Pentagon says an Iranian operative captured in Iraq on Thursday and accused of helping Iraqi insurgents was acting under orders from the elite Quds Force. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.The U.S. military command in Iraq says the man was arrested in Sulimaniyah Province in the northeast along the Iranian border. The command says the unidentified man is an officer of the Quds Force, an elite unit of Iran's Revolutionary Guards Corps. It says he was involved in transporting special, high-technology roadside bombs that have the power to pierce the armor of U.S. military vehicles. A U.S. military statement says there are indications from intelligence agencies that the man was also involved in training foreign fighters and smuggling them into Iraq.About six other alleged Quds force members have been detained in Iraq on similar charges, but U.S. officials have said they are not sure whether the men are operating under orders from the highest levels of the Iranian government.Still, Pentagon Press Secretary Geoff Morrell said Thursday it appears this latest detainee was not operating on his own."The Quds Force is a tightly controlled paramilitary force for the government of Iran," he said. "So I think it seems to us as though, indeed, he's not operating as a Lone Ranger in Iraq, but he has been presumably ordered to be there."

A typical math problem for an American middle school student might be to calculate the sales tax on a dozen baseball caps. At an after-school program called the Berkeley Math Circle, a typical problem is more? advanced. As she writes the hyperbolic cosine formula on the blackboard, circle director Zvezda Stankova asks the four dozen or so teens in the room to use it in a differential equation to describe the arc of a wire, hanging between two poles.It's no problem for 12-year-old Bobby Veres, who says Math Circle teens can handle this. He points out, "It's very prestigious. Most of the top math kids from around the Bay area come here. I like the chance that we get to learn extra math that isn't available in schools, and we get to make friends."They also get to hear from some top mathematicians and theorists, like astrophysicist Cliff Stoll. Stankova calls him the epitome of what you would think of an internationally renown scientist: "Absent-minded, yet very animated. Very sharp and very enthusiastic." And very demonstrative. Stoll is jumping high, spreading his arms wide, then running forward until he's nose to nose with the Math Circle students - all this to show the three dimensions of our universe: height, width and depth. With Stoll in command, the Math Circle takes a wild ride from our 3-D universe to an imaginary world of two dimensions, that's limited to only width and height. "Can I tie a knot in a string that's in a two-dimensional universe?" he asks, prompting a chorus of "No!" When one student says "yes," Stoll challenges him to prove it.

Ladi Recac of El Salvador is one of the most spectacular and best known birds in the world.The bird is the first bird to fly into space (or at least the first bird to successfully fly into space without the aid of astronauts) and is now in the process of making a second successful flight with the same goal, to become the first bird to fly into space and return to Earth with humans.That is a big and important undertaking, which involves a whole host of technical aspects and scientific knowledge.The most important piece of technology needed for Ladi Recac is a miniature aircraft that can carry the bird safely and at a controlled speed. The first one is the Blue Racer, an aircraft built in the Philippines and the first one that can carry a bird on it.In the United States, the Wright Flyer was the first airplane with a single winged aircraft. That plane had a small wing area and, therefore, a small wingspan to be able to carry the wings of a bird.The Blue Racer has a full sized wing (wingspan is over 35 meters, wingspan is 40 meters) and is capable of carrying not only the wings of the Ladi Recac, but also the wings of Ladi Recac's co-pilot and another bird.Blue Racer is also an amazing bird flying, having reached a speed of almost 300 km/h. And, for that it needs the same technology that allowed Ladi Recac to fly into space and return to Earth: the wing of an airplane.One of the things that makes Blue Racer so impressive is its ability to fly at that speed."The Blue Racer is one of the best known birds in the world, as it is considered one of the most powerful and fastest birds in the world. If it can fly at that speed, why can't it also fly at the same speed without any assistance?" said Dr.

Nepalese police have arrested at least 50 journalists after scuffling with them during a protest against media restrictions imposed by the royal government.The members of the Federation of Nepalese Journalists were arrested as they marched into a restricted area near the royal palace.They were demanding an immediate restoration of press freedom and an end to harassment and arrests by security forces.Police bundled the journalists into buses and drove them away.Journalists have held several protests since February first, when King Gyanendra seized absolute power. The government arrested 53 journalists during a similar protest last Wednesday, but released them a day later.Last week, the Vienna-based International Press Institute told the king in a statement that "the best antidote to the present situation in the country is more speech and greater discussion."Some information for this report provided by AP and AFP.

SANTIAGO - Taxi drivers in Chile protested on Thursday against ride-hailing app Uber, as authorities indicated they were considering more regulatory oversight to deal with car-sharing services.Blocking an avenue in downtown Santiago, the taxi drivers' demonstration was the latest in a series around the globe against the service, which critics say is unsafe, skirts labor laws and depresses wages."I don't have a problem that they work - we all have a right to earn money - but this has reduced our business a lot," said taxi driver Jaime Poblete Soto, 30. "The [drop in customers] has become very obvious."On Wednesday, a similar anti-Uber protest took place in the Argentine city of Cordoba, and in late March four men torched an Uber vehicle in Nairobi, Kenya.Massive Uber protests have also taken place in recent months in Brazil, Mexico, France and several other nations.Taxi drivers in France and other countries have been protesting Uber's operations and calling for them to be suspended, Paris, Jan. 26, 2016.Uber Chile, which started in December 2014 and now has around 10,000 registered drivers, according to the company, has repeatedly called on national authorities to establish a clearer regulatory framework for ride-sharing apps.As of now, the company said, drivers operate in a legal gray zone."What we do isn't covered by current law, so we've asked for help in trying to find a way to regulate this, but we've been told 'no,'" said Carlos Schaaf, chief executive of Uber Chile."

BEIJING (AP) — China's president began a three-nation European tour Thursday after a state visit to the Vatican to boost relations with the Catholic Church in one of his first foreign trips since he took office.President Xi Jinping visited Moscow and Moscow and Budapest before arriving in Berlin. Xi arrived in Germany at 2:53 p.m.

NegotiationsThe head of an international panel of experts on the reconciliation process in Somalia says he is cautiously optimistic that the Islamist leaders whose group has been excluded will be brought into the negotiations.The panel's vice chair, a senior foreign service officer from the United States, expressed satisfaction that the Somali government had not yet completely excluded religious leaders who have opposed the peace talks.But he said the Islamist leaders must be represented in the upcoming talks so they can "make a clear and positive contribution to the process."In January, Somalia's presidency said the talks would take place without excluded figures after a compromise was reached with the president of the Federal Government, Prime Minister Mohammed Abdullahi Mohamed. The panel's vice chair was a State Department representative in 2009 when Mohamed was president.The panel has been meeting with the prime minister, senior security officials and representatives of the Federal Government and the central administration of Somalia. They have been meeting in the capital, Mogadishu, to try to hammer out how to ensure that the peace talks, led by Mohamed, can move forward without the threat of an Islamic insurgency to derail them.Some moderate religious figures were excluded in the talks, though they have continued to press the government for the exclusion of some of the main religious leaders. The government did exclude some clerics, including some of the influential ones.The exclusion of the Islamist leaders has been viewed as a political win by those pushing for more radical Islamist groups in the talks.Mohamed, who was also the vice chair of the panel, said at a news conference in the capital, Mogadishu, on April 25 that the Islamists had a chance to be involved in the negotiations."

Violent crime in the United States fell in the first half of 2017, according to a preliminary report released Tuesday by the FBI, but the number of homicides rose in the same period.Property crimes declined by nearly three full percentage points over the same period.For the first six months of 2017, overall violent crime decreased 0.8 percentage point compared with the same time period in 2016. In comparison, the nationwide violent crime rate increased by nearly 7 percent during 2015 and 2016.Rates of violent crime in cities with more than a million residents fell by 3.3 percentage points. Property crime rates fell most in smaller cities with populations below 50,000.Also during the first half of 2017, rapes decreased 2.4 percentage points; robberies decreased 2.2 percentage points; and aggravated assaults were down 0.1 percentage point. All three categories increased during the same period in 2016.In an op-ed piece published by USA Today on Tuesday, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said the statistics proved that President Donald Trump has kept a promise he made at his inauguration to end "This American carnage."

The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) aims to boost investments in Arab countries to 2.5 billion euros ($2.92 billion) at the end of 2018 from 2.2 billion in 2017, a senior official said Tuesday.The bank, set up by governments in 1991 to support the ex-Communist states of eastern Europe, has expanded its mandate in the past few years to invest in Jordan, Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt."Last year we had a record 2.2 billion euros invested in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt and Jordan," said Janet Heckman, managing director for the southern and eastern Mediterranean region at the bank."

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on Wednesday asked the UN Security Council for measures to put pressure on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad over his chemical weapons program.Russian Ambassador Georgy Rogozin told reporters that Russia was "requesting that the Council take action in the form of individual sanctions against individuals."While the Russian ambassador declined to say whom he was talking about, Russian state news agency RIA Novosti identified them as the main opposition factions currently opposing al-Assad's regime and calling for a military intervention."The UN Security Council should take immediate action by imposing individual sanctions against individuals who, in turn, must implement any actions that are required," RIA quoted Rogozin as saying.Rogozin did not indicate whether the UN Security Council would agree to the proposed sanctions. Russia and China are both veto-wielding members of the Security Council."They should not ignore this issue.

Four young men who recently graduated from high school have become radio broadcasters in Haromaya district of eastern Hararghe. Jamal Asee, Usmael Alisho, Zahir Usman and Zakir Abdul-Karim started experimenting in 2002 in an effort to create a mobile phone. They dismantled their radio sets, reassembled and reconnected the parts of the radios on a large hardboard to make a transmitter with enough power to relay broadcasts to a 36-kilometer range.

(ISNA, June 16, 2021) – Estonia's Supreme Court has opened the trial of a former Soviet officer charged with genocide in the former Soviet Union.Taimi Eljelianov, a member of the Estonian People's Party (EKRE), is one of 13 defendants being prosecuted in Estonia's capital Tallinn.The former officer was charged in August 2020 with the crimes of mass murder and genocide during the Russian Civil War, between 1923 and 1922, and the subsequent occupation of the country by the Soviet Union, during which the Estonian population was killed, maimed, or forced to leave the country.Eljelianov denies any such charges and says the events occurred during a personal crisis in his life, exacerbated by the deaths of his father and grandmother.The trial opened on Tuesday with a witness whose father was shot dead in Moscow by the Red Army during the Great Patriotic War.Eljelianov said he "absolutely" denies the charge."I'm innocent of all the crimes mentioned, but I'm guilty of them," he said, claiming he would have been killed for his political views if not for his father.

The Republican National Convention is just a month away. But the campaign to win the White House is only just beginning.Here are some ways to shape the GOP's message and message against Barack Obama.1. Get to the heart of the message. Make the connection between Obama's policies and Republican values.2. Make people understand that the GOP is a force for change.3. Don't try to be everything to everyone. Be an advocate for a few values at a time and find ways to appeal to all Americans.4. Don't be seen as being against any group or ideology. Instead, you should portray the GOP as the party for all Americans. This allows you to appeal to those who don't fit the party label.5. Make an argument for Republican principles. You can't please everyone, but by framing a specific case for Republican ideals, you can appeal to moderates as well as conservative-leaning Republicans.6. Focus on the issues that matter most to people, and you can make those a litmus test for presidential candidates.7. Make your case in terms you believe the other side isn't willing to listen to. These include: why you don't want health care reform, why your kids are on the welfare system, what your income taxes are like, how the Middle East is threatening our national security, and so on.8. Emphasize that this is an election about a candidate and not an issue. Don't try to make a blanket argument against Obama but instead pick out some policies from his record that represent the views of the GOP, and present those as reasons why you'd vote for that candidate.9. Tell a story that connects people to the party. Your story is about you and your family, but it can be about your hometown or your favorite political figure. Make sure the story contains the same themes as the party platform, such as that the story can be told as one person's story but it can also be a vision for how things might work if your candidates win.10. Make sure everyone understands how your message will be delivered. The point isn't to win votes, it's to get people onside.11. Don't try to fit the message for the candidate into a specific message for the party. Don't try to fit the message in the party platform.

The U.S. financial crisis continued to dominate the presidential campaign Friday, as both major party candidates for the White House spoke about what they would do to deal with the market turmoil. VOA National correspondent Jim Malone has more from Washington. Republican candidate John McCain spoke in Wisconsin and said the U.S. central bank should stop bailing out failed financial institutions, and should return to the main job of managing the money supply and guarding against inflation.McCain said that, if elected president, he would set up a Mortgage and Financial Institutions Trust, MFI for short, which he says would help homeowners avoid foreclosure."The MFI will restore investor and market confidence, build sound financial institutions, assist troubled institutions and protect our financial system, while minimizing taxpayer exposure," he said.McCain also ramped up the attacks on his Democratic opponent, Senator Barack Obama. McCain said Obama's ties to the failed mortgage lenders Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, including campaign contributions, make him part of the problem."We've heard a lot of words from Senator Obama over the course of this campaign," he said. "But maybe, just this once, he could spare us the lectures, and admit to his own poor judgment in contributing to these problems."

, but Must Be CarefulANKARA, Turkey — It took little more than a month for the European Union to deny Turkey a vote on membership.But Turkey is now trying to rally support for a European election bid for the second time in less than six years, hoping to make good on its promise to make good on a pledge to join the bloc.“We believe that we deserve to become an EU candidate country, but we need a bit more help,” Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu told a news conference in Istanbul on Monday.“We are seeking to mobilize the best talents and the best efforts to make a political-economic package for this country to become an EU candidate country,” Davutoglu added.The EU refused to grant Turkey a vote last year because of allegations of Turkish involvement in Syria.The bloc’s executive arm, the European Commission, cited “a lack of certainty over Turkey’s role in the crisis” for its decision.But the EU executive arm, the European Commission, said there is “a lack of clarity with Turkey’s behavior during the crisis” and thus a lack of certainty about Ankara’s role in the conflict.“We are doing very well at the moment,” said Davutoglu. “The EU is in a much better position, with much more stability and a better security situation … and much better development opportunities.”Davutoglu said that “Turkey should take advantage of the opportunity, which will be open in July, to launch a new political program.”Turkey has been fighting Islamic State militants in northern Syria since the start of the conflict, but it has had a tense relationship with the European Union over its human rights record and involvement in the Syrian war.In August, the EU’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said Turkey would not get an EU vote.Turkey’s presidency has been running under an interim caretaker setup. The new prime minister, Tansuada Demir, has promised a new election will take place in July.But many believe this will come at a cost, given Turkey is not yet ready to meet the political and economic standards set for entry into the bloc.“

Bosnia and Herzegovina has signed an agreement with the UN to provide refugees with a legal route to the European Union, but a controversial dispute over the wording of the deal has left the government unable to implement it in full.The government of Belgian Prime Minister, Sophie Wilmès, has been left behind in the wake of the agreement, which, once it has passed the parliamentary procedure and become law, will allow the Bosnian Serbs to obtain the EU visa-free status they currently have, but will not give them the right to reside in Belgium.Belgian citizens are expected to make up about 90 percent of the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina, where the EU is expected to expand its presence to include the republic by 2026 and it is not expected for EU citizenship to have to go back to Bosnia and Herzegovina.The Bosnian Serbs, who remain inside Bosnia and Herzegovina, want the Bosnian Croats who left the country during the conflict to be able to apply for EU citizenship, and vice versa.The agreement was signed by Wilmès, United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, and EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, but as of Monday has been approved only by the parliament.As a result, the agreement, which was presented as an EU deal with the Bosnian Serbs on Monday, cannot go into effect unless it is approved by the parliament, where Bosnian Serb parties control two out of three seats.According to one source, if the parliament were to be dissolved, the agreement would fall through.An agreement between the two sides was also considered in March 2018, but the agreement failed to be approved by the parliament.Both sides were reluctant to accept the agreement because of the differences between the Bosnian Serb Party, led by Zoran Milanovic, and the party of president, Milorad Dodik, the Bosnian Croat Party, led by Dusan Vujovic.Milanovic said he wanted Bosnia and Herzegovina to be a single entity, whereas Vujovic wants the Bosnian Serbs to remain inside Bosnia and Herzegovina, except that the majority of the population should be Bosniac or Muslim.Milanovic told Bosnians and Muslims to
