Just hours after top U.S. national security leaders made a rare joint appearance in the White House briefing room Thursday to express concern about efforts by Russia and potentially others to meddle in upcoming U.S. elections, U.S. President Donald Trump made an appearance at a rally where he seemed to be unable to come down hard on Russian President Vladimir Putin, even in the face of the mounting evidence of Russian election interference."I got along great with Putin," Trump said at the rally.Trump again accused the media of writing fake news, calling media reports of Russian interference in U.S. elections a hoax.The president’s rally remarks conflicted with the statements the national security leaders made earlier in the day.WATCH: US National Security Team Concerned About Efforts to Meddle in 2018 Election"We continue to see a pervasive message campaign by Russia to try to weaken and divide the United States," said the director of national intelligence, Dan Coats, adding that he is aware "Russia is not the only country that has an interest in trying to influence our domestic political environment."Coats said President Trump "has specifically directed us to make the matter of election meddling and securing our election process a top priority."FBI Director Christopher Wray, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Army General Paul Nakasone, who is head of the National Security Agency, also appeared at Thursday's briefing.As they spoke, a letter national security adviser John Bolton sent to five senators of the opposition Democratic Party was released outlining the Trump administration's "extensive, historic actions" taken to "ensure the integrity of our elections and defend against foreign malign influence."

Two Journalists Escape Siege in Northern Zimbabwe by Militants – 2002-08-14ByEzine EjioforPublished time: 04:22, August 14, 2002Two journalists were killed by militants in Zororo (North-Eastern Zimbabwe) who are also said to be fighting Mugabe for a better state of affairs there.The journalists, Chikanga and Ndudzo (not in the above photo) worked for the online newspaper ZimLive.com and were attacked in a town of about 50 000 people.They were being driven through Zororo in an anti-Mugabe militia vehicle when the militants fired on them.According to ZimLive.com, the convoy of journalists was stopped at Mhondoro-Dondo by armed men who ordered them to drop their mobile phones which they did.As they waited, a military van and helicopter arrived.The fighters opened fire on the convoy, wounding the journalist and several other people, who were able to escape.The militants then fled in a helicopter, taking up positions around Mugabe's rural village."Mugabe's militia still has a substantial number of fighters and vehicles which would allow them to harass the remaining unarmed journalists."

MR. MORALES: The Iraq war began a little more than a month ago. The "shock and awe" campaign started on March 20th with allied air strikes against leadership targets as US and British forces rolled across the border from Kuwait.On April 5th, American heavy armor penetrated Baghdad. And today, what fighting remains is largely mopping-up pockets of resistance as the U-S leads the post-war reconstruction of Iraq.How was the war won so quickly? And what are the lessons to be learned?Joining me to examine the Iraq war are: military strategist, retired US Army Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Peters; and military historian Victor Davis Hanson of California State University in Fresno, Califronia.Victor Hanson, let me begin with you. In your view, what was the key factor in the coalition victory in Iraq?MR. HANSON: I think it was the ability to start the ground war almost simultaneously with the air war that gave some tactical surprise, when it was hard to achieve surprise because of the past record in Afghanistan and Kosovo, where we didn't use sizeable numbers of ground troops. It saved the infrastructure. It undermined the Iraqi command-and-control. And it gave some powerful messages that we still could act without our allies, such as Turkey or Saudi Arabia. We sort of envisioned the Iraqis -- the Baathists -- as a snake of sorts that was coiled around the Tigris and Euphrates Valley, and rather than just hacking at the coils, we went straight to Baghdad and tried to decapitate it.MR. MORALES: Ralph Peters, let me put that same question to you.MR. PETERS: I certainly agree with everything that has just been said as far as the operational factors go, but I think there is something even beyond that. This really was a civilizational victory.

Thousands of Kenyan civilians have died in the hands of police since 2009, according to a rights group. The violence has often been accompanied by clashes that have left hundreds of civilians dead and injured, according to Amnesty International Kenya.Kenyan police have also killed civilians in recent attacks in Somalia, it said in a news release on Wednesday.The police were accused of trying to quell dissent after a group of Kenyan youths attacked a Kenya Border Guard (KGB) police station during an election in 2007.Kenyan police had reportedly opened fire on people in the vicinity of the station. The police alleged that a group of young Kenyans had tried to attack another station when they were on their way there.The alleged attack on the station, which happened in December 2007, triggered clashes between Kenyan police and the group of youths.When the youths attacked the station, they were surrounded and shot by the police, the group claimed.At least 1,000 people died in the incidents, including 300 who were killed in an attack the same year in neighbouring Somalia, according to a report by the BBC.But the Kenya Police Command has denied that it has used excessive force to quell unrest and claimed that the police have only acted professionally.Rights group Amnesty International has accused police of using excessive force and using live bullets against civilians. The rights group says that at least 1,300 Kenyans died during police violence in the country last year.Kenya has come under fire in recent years for its treatment of its citizens abroad.The country has been accused of human rights abuses and has been blamed for a number of deaths by some countries including the US and the UK.

ISLAMABAD - Pakistan says it is “sincerely” making efforts to reach a negotiated end to the conflict in Afghanistan because doing so would address Islamabad’s own security concerns and encourage millions of Afghan refugees and migrants who have lived in Pakistan for decades to return to their country.National Security Adviser Nasir Janjua made the remarks Tuesday, a day before senior Afghan, Pakistani, Chinese and American diplomats are scheduled to meet in Islamabad to explore ways to start peace talks between the Kabul government and the Taliban.It will be the fifth meeting this year for the parties, known as the Quadrilateral Coordination Group, or QCG.The four-nation group earlier finalized a road map to peace but has not persuaded the Taliban to join talks with the Afghan government.Deep differences remain between Kabul and Islamabad on how to push the Taliban to the negotiating table.“These are trying times, challenging times. We are passing through it together. We have some differences, differences in our outlook. We are very sincerely trying to help out [in] the reconciliation. We are trying to play our role in bringing peace to Afghanistan and also to our restive areas. I am sure together we have a shared future,” Janjua said.The lack of progress on peace talks plus increased Taliban attacks are fueling tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan, where insurgent commanders are allegedly sheltering.Waiting for a decisionAfghan President Ashraf Ghani repeated his demand last week that the time has come for Islamabad to deliver on its commitments.“All four (QCG) states committed to a road map and their obligations, particularly by the state of Pakistan. Those obligations are that if Taliban groups prove irreconcilable then there will be use of force.

DUBAI (Sputnik) — On Thursday, Iranian President Hasan Rouhani announced the deployment of the country's Revolutionary Guards (IRGC) "to restore peace and security in Syria."“The Islamic Republic of Iran is fully committed to the sovereignty of Syria and to the sovereignty and independence of all of the other countries," he said.Iran and Turkey have been at odds since the Turkish Armed Forces, which backs the Kurdish militias, launched Operation Euphrates Shield, in Syria's northern Syrian provinces of Raqqa and Aleppo in early October. Ankara accused the YPG terrorists of being part of a Kurdish-controlled "terror network" in Syria. However, the Syrian government accused Turkey of backing the Kurdish forces in Syria, which are seeking to oust the Islamic State terror group (banned in Russia).© AFP 2018 / SAHD REWIS Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan calls for new Syrian border crossing, 'new zone'In December 2015, a truce was agreed to restore peace and security in Syria.Moscow and Ankara have maintained close ties since the founding of the Soviet Union. In 1992, Turkish President Turgut Ozyakin and Russian President Boris Yeltsin signed a memorandum on the settlement of territorial dispute.However, relations between the two NATO members have been strained by a number of domestic, international and regional issues since Russia’s military actions in Syria.

Eritrea has invited Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir to make an official visit, in defiance of an international court's move to arrest Sudan's president for alleged crimes against humanity.Eritrea's foreign minister, Osman Saleh, delivered the invitation from President Isaias Afewerki to Bashir during a meeting in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, on Tuesday. Eritrea's information minister, Ali Abdu, told the Tigrigna and Amharic services that Bashir has accepted the invitation, but that a date for the visit has not been set. Ali Abdu said, "the ICC allegation violates Sudanese sovereignty and territorial integrity, and hence it is unjustified, and unacceptable and totally unwarranted." He said, "External politics would not solve Sudanese problem, but comprehensive and lasting solution on the basis of Sudan-Sudan approach."The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Bashir last week. Prosecutors accuse him of being behind a campaign of murder, rape and other crimes against civilians in Darfur, where Sudan's government has been fighting rebels since 2003. Mr.

KURASHIKI, JAPAN - Japan risks more severe weather and must find ways to alleviate disasters, a government spokesman said Thursday, as intense heat and water shortages raised fear of disease among survivors of its worst weather disaster in 36 years.Torrential rain that struck western Japan a week ago caused floods and landslides, killing 200 people, many in communities that have existed for decades on mountain slopes and flood plains largely untroubled by storms.But severe weather has been battering the country more regularly in recent years, raising questions about the impact of global warming. Dozens of people were killed in a similar disaster last year.FILE - Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga speaks to the media during a press conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo.“It’s an undeniable fact that this sort of disaster due to torrential, unprecedented rain is becoming more frequent in recent years,” Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga told a news conference in Tokyo.Saving lives was the government’s biggest duty, he said.“

Climate change was among the most contentious agenda items Friday at the Group of Seven (G-7) summit in Sicily, but both American and British government officials are publicly denying any major discord. The leaders had a “very good discussion” about climate issues, British Prime Minister Theresa May told reporters, adding there was “no doubt around the table” -- which included U.S. President Donald Trump -- about how important the issue is. Trump “is taking in what he learned from world leaders today” to make his decision on whether to honor Washington’s commitment to cut greenhouse gas emissions under the Paris Agreement signed two years ago, according to the president’s chief economic advisor, Gary Cohn.Watch: Climate Change, Migration, North Korea, Terrorism Dominate Trump's 1st G-7 MeetingSorry, but your browser cannot support embedded video of this type, you can download this video to view it offline.U.S. administration officials have said Trump, who referred to man-made global warming as a “hoax” during his successful presidential campaign last year, would wait until after the summit before making a decision on the issue. The G-7, going back more than a decade, has repeatedly recognized the threat of climate change. Closely watched will be the specific language issued about the subject in the Taormina communique, expected to be released late Friday or early Saturday. “It would be extremely rare for this major set of developed countries to not send a clear signal regarding climate change,” according to Jake Schmidt, the international program director of the National Resources Defense Council.

NEW DELHI - They occupy only 25 per cent of the work force, less than 12 per cent of parliamentary seats, a backseat in many homes dominated by patriarchal voices, but in one significant area Indian women have emerged on par with men: at polling booths. That has made political parties sit up and take notice in a country where a slim margin can make the difference between victory and defeat. To mark women’s empowerment, the Election Commission set up hundreds of “pink booths” in the country during the five-week general election that wraps up Sunday. In the capital, New Delhi, several polling stations were festooned with balloons and staffed with women and volunteers who handed out roses and sweets setting a festive atmosphere. There may well be reason to celebrate: the hope is that this general election will virtually close the voter gap between men and women, which five decades ago stood at 15 per cent but narrowed down to one and a half per cent five years ago. “The elimination of the gender gap in turnout would be a monumental achievement, especially in a conservative, patriarchal society like India’s,” says Milan Vaishnav, Director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment. “In 2019, nearly all parties are touting their pro-women credentials if for no other reason than they cannot afford to alienate a growing segment of the electorate.”

YANGON (Reuters) - President Joe Biden's new U.S. State Department policy of a "full and effective implementation" of the 1915 Genocide Convention (GC) does not guarantee action from U.S. allies and partners over Myanmar's violent crackdown on Rohingya Muslims, rights advocates said on Friday."This is not a war that will ever end," said William N. Hartung, a prominent lawyer and former U.S. ambassador to Burma who also serves on the advisory board of the Center for a Democratic Ethic in Human Relations."There's a terrible feeling of a lack of a sense of urgency," Hartung said by telephone from Yangon.Biden announced on Wednesday that the United States and its partners would use the GC to "achieve full and effective implementation" of international law against genocide of ethnic Rohingya Muslim minority in Myanmar.More than 750,000 members of Myanmar's Rohingya Muslim minority fled to neighboring Bangladesh after an army crackdown in response to attacks in June on security posts by a Rohingya insurgent group known as the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army. The government has accused the Rohingya militants of trying to stir up ethnic discord.Myanmar, known by its initials BMF, says it is committed to rooting out terrorism and has taken several steps to ensure security.But with the military's return to power in 2012, renewed violence and a crackdown on Muslims has continued. The military says it is defending its people from attackers and that thousands of Rohingya are returning to their villages."This new State Department policy is good in the long run but doesn't guarantee that it will result in effective implementation," said Hartung, a senior analyst at the U.S.-based Wilson Center think tank and a legal advisor to then U.S. President Bill Clinton's administration."U.S. foreign policy will continue to evolve," Hartung said. "The administration and President Biden will continue to be on the offensive and will continue to work with other countries, particularly in Asia, on security in Asia."At least 12 members of the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army were killed in a raid on a village by Myanmar's army on Sept. 8, according to a group of Rohingya refugees who escaped from a village they said was attacked by army forces in the middle of the night.Myanmar soldiers have said several civilians also were killed in the same raid in the Arakan region.

GAZA CITY, GAZA STRIP - Egypt on Wednesday trucked 1 million liters of cheap diesel fuel to the Gaza Strip's sole power plant — a rare shipment that temporarily eased a crippling electricity crisis in the Hamas-ruled enclave but also appeared to undercut Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.Abbas has been stepping up financial pressure on Gaza in hopes of forcing the militant group Hamas to cede ground in the territory. Hamas seized Gaza from Abbas' forces in 2007. The power plant stopped operating in April after Hamas could no longer afford to buy heavily taxed fuel from Abbas' West Bank-based government, leaving Gazans with just four hours of electricity a day. Abbas also asked Israel to reduce the electricity it sends to Gaza, which amounts to about a third of the territory's needs. This electricity, paid for by the Abbas government, has been reduced by one-fourth since Monday, worsening the crunch. The power shortage has cast a pall over the current holy month of Ramadan, when Muslims often end their dawn-to-dusk fasting with lavish family meals. With their homes in the dark and refrigerators not functioning, families have had to scale back the celebrations. Yousef al-Kayali, a Hamas finance official, said 11 trucks delivered the fuel on Wednesday. He said a second shipment of an additional 1 million liters was expected by Thursday. The fuel will not solve Gaza's electricity woes, however. Israel is now providing just 88 megawatts of power each day, down from 120 megawatts earlier this week.

, After 8 Month InterrogationMohamed Farouq, the former Egyptian ambassador to the United States, is making a triumphant return to the Cairo court on Friday, after being imprisoned for eight months, in connection with the so-called “Cairo Trials.”Farouq was being tried for “inciting the public to overthrow the government,” for an alleged tweet in which he was quoted as saying that “no one is allowed to challenge the military’s decisions or its authority.”After spending eight months in jail, he was released last Wednesday by military prosecutors, and was immediately re-arrested and detained again.He spent another eight months in custody before being convicted on July 5th, after being tried by a military court of “inciting public opinion to overthrow the state.”However, by Wednesday, his attorney, Gamal Fattah, had filed an appeal with the military’s Supreme Court that argued that “the trial should have been closed to the public in order to preserve the right to fair hearing under Article 6 of the Egyptian Constitution and Article 1 of the French Constitution”The judge presiding over Farouq’s trial issued an order on August 1st that allowed for a hearing for the public, but that the hearing had to be closed to “the defense and prosecution.”His supporters have argued that this was a ploy by the military to allow Farouq to “surprise” and “surprise the prosecution.”Farouq was sentenced to between ten and twenty years in prison under the military prosecution law, despite his conviction on a separate charge of “inciting the public to overthrow the state.”

Palestinian medics say a young Palestinian girl has been killed in an Israeli air strike in the Gaza Strip, after an Israeli died in a cross-border mortar attackA Palestinian mortar shell fired from the Gaza Strip slammed into an Israeli kibbutz (collective farm), Thursday. It resulted in the second killing of a kibbutz resident in two weeks."The situation is intolerable," said Chaim Yalin, the head of the regional council in the area. He told Israel Radio that Gaza border communities have been bombarded daily for years and the that government and army are doing nothing. He says Israelis are being buried every week and that no one seems to care.The Islamic militant group Hamas, which rules Gaza, claims responsibility for the attack. Hamas issued a statement saying that it would confront what it calls "the occupier," because of what Hamas calls its continuing aggression against the Palestinian people. Hamas is especially angry about a crippling Israeli blockade on Gaza, imposed in response to the rocket and mortar fire.Israeli Cabinet Minister Roni Bar-On says there is only one solution.Bar-On told Israel Radio that the army must launch a major offensive in Gaza, to put an end to the Palestinian cross-border attacks.

Some 30,000 people in Yemens are escaping from fighting in the country with their children, the United Nations announced in a statement published Wednesday in the state capital of Puntland.The statement was issued to mark the end of an International Organization for Migration’s (OIM) ongoing humanitarian response to violence in the southern half of the country.The OIM is responsible for delivering the emergency assistance in order to improve the situation of more than 50,000 people in the three areas of Al Jubur, Badr and Zuwayl.A total of 23,000 people are in transit in these areas.More than 40% of the Yemens population are displaced and some 30,000 people are in a “dangerous and urgent” situation due to violence and destruction of infrastructure.In the area of Zuwayl, almost 10,000 civilians had already fled the fighting which was mainly between pro-government forces and rebels, with 10,000 refugees also in danger from an intensification of fighting.Many Yemens families have become internally displaced by the fighting but others have fled to neighboring Somaliland for protection, the statement said.For more than 10 years, since 2009 when fighting erupted in central Yemens against separatists who wanted to break away from Ethiopia, Somaliland has been a safe haven for people fleeing to neighboring regions in search of protection.Some 10,000 refugees have so far fled from Zuwayl, Badr and Al Jubur as a result of the fighting between pro-government forces and rebels in the area.In November 2016, OIM said that violence could cause more than 6,000 people to flee the country, adding that about 1,500 families have left Badr.Yemens have expressed concern over displacement of civilians to Somaliland.The OIM said more than 14,000 families have been displaced in Zuwayl.(

Japan is still pushing for sanctions against North Korea for last week's missile tests - a day after the U.N. Security Council delayed a vote to allow more time for diplomacy. Meanwhile, South Korea has criticized Japan for talk of possible pre-emptive military action against North Korea - saying it is intensifying the crisis.Japan's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Tomohiko Taniguchi, says Tokyo still wants U.N. Security Council sanctions imposed on North Korea for its July 5 missile tests in the Sea of Japan."But we have just decided to put on hold for 24 hours or maximum 48 hours for the Chinese will come back with more concrete ideas about what North Korea has had to say to China," said Taniguchi.The Security Council delayed a vote Monday to allow a Chinese delegation to talk to the North Koreans in Pyongyang.U.S. envoy, Christopher Hill is in Asia to get regional governments to respond with one voice.But differences persist. China opposes U.N. sanctions. South Korea questions their effectiveness. Japan is talking about changing its pacifist stance to allow pre-emptive military action against North Korea - something South Korea criticized Tuesday as reckless.

BAGHDAD - Iraqi voters have started voting in their first presidential election since the victory over the Islamic State group, but turnout at least compared to the 2014 vote was low.It was unclear whether the low turnout would have any effect on whether the government can win support among the country's many minorities — the Sunni majority and Shiites — who may be wary of a post-war government.But the low turnout could hurt Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's chances of getting re-elected. This could help strengthen the Iraqi opposition, which has been trying to form a government since last year.The vote's first phase, in which Iraqis cast their ballots for their preferred candidates, had a little more than 8 million voters eligible, according to the Interior Ministry.There has been a lot of talk about turnout but turnout actually has been lower than last year.Turnout in the 2014 elections was about 45%. This is actually higher than the turnout in Iraq's first election in 2004, which was also held under security of the Islamic State group.This time around, a quarter of voters voted in the first round, and the other five in the remaining rounds.Polling stations were opened at 7 a.m. (0500 GMT) on Tuesday to avoid any confusion caused by people opening their ballots on Tuesday evening.Al-Abadi's office released results from polling stations across the country on Tuesday, with a small number of people having cast ballots since voting began last week.The Interior Ministry said that turnout for the first round was 23,818. It said 8,611 of the ballots had come from the Shiite part of the country, while 2,507 were from the Sunni part of the country.The official turnout figures from the vote were yet to be released.Last year, Abadi secured a majority vote of more than 50% and won an absolute majority in parliament.

A peaceful transition to democracy in Tunisia proved to be a rare success story of the Arab Spring, yet as one official says, "many challenges" remain for the country.Tunisia was fortunate to have pragmatic politicians who favored compromise over confrontation. The Islamist political party Ennahda, which won the first elections after the 2011 revolution, voluntarily handed over power to a technocrat government. A strong civil society in Tunisia also helped with the move away from autocracy.However, Faycal Gouia, Tunisia's ambassador to the United States, says his country still faces serious problems going forward.“We are facing so many challenges internally because of the terrorist attacks on Tunisia, [and] secondly because of the many problems we are facing which represent the inheritance of the former regime, especially 23 years of authoritarian regime,” Gouia said. He said “problems like poverty, unemployment and the huge gap between the coastal land cities and the inland spread despair among young Tunisians.”Meanwhile, Libya is a nation in chaos with two battling governments, scores of militias and a security vacuum being filled by a growing presence of the Islamic State extremist group on Tunisia's border.“Islamic State fighters took advantage of the political fragmentation in Libya to occupy the coastal city of Sirte and succeeded in bringing a large number of foreign fighters across the uncontrolled borders,” said Wafa Bugaighis, Libyan charge d’affaires in Washington. “Intelligence estimates state that there are between 5,000 and 7,000 IS fighters in Libya."

PresidentLIMA — The head of Bolivia’s military said Sunday that dialogue with the United States to find a solution to the ongoing political and economic crisis is “necessary.”The statement by Gen. Williams Kaliman is a direct response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s threat to shut the Bolivian border with Peru and bar humanitarian aid to the nation.Kaliman’s comments follow a statement by U.S.

After Nearly 10 Years Without A Form of GovernmentMozambique’s president, Filipe Nyusi, who has already been in office for nearly 10 years, said he wanted a new government before November, to help fight the jihadist attacks that have rocked the north since 2011.As Mozambique continues to battle the attacks of ISIS-supported groups, it must prepare for elections in 2018, and is not only going to win the battle, but will also use the new elections to set up new governing institutions and develop political and governance structures.Mozambique has long been ruled under a hybrid form of government, alternating between multiparty and single-party systems. The elections have been regularly delayed, and have been postponed three times since the beginning of the jihadist attacks of 2011 in the south.Mozambique is in a state of turmoil, with more than 1,000 dead, hundreds of thousands displaced, and an uncertain future for the country.

FINISTERE, BRITTANY - After turning a 15th century stone mansion in Brittany into a comfortable bed & breakfast, Scotsman Peter Dinwiddie was left with what he calls a “messy” predicament. What to do with a pair of dilapidated buildings on the edge of his property?Today Dinwiddie, who moved to this bucolic slice of far western France known as the Finistere more than a decade ago, has found the solution. Solar panels glisten from atop a now elegant stone veranda — Dinwiddie’s contribution to a larger energy transition.“We don’t use the electricity as such,” he said ruefully. “We sell it back into the energy grid, and buy it back at half the price from EDF… which is a bit crazy, really.”EDF, or Electricite de France, is France’s national power company, which operates the country’s 58 nuclear power plants, although it also has a renewable energy wing. But to install his solar panels, Dinwiddie turned to Quenea, one of dozens of local companies now mushrooming around the area.As negotiators from 195 nations try to reach a climate deal in Paris, regional and local governments aren’t waiting. Many are forging ahead with their own climate action plans that are sometimes more ambitious than national ones.“If you look at the delivery and implementation of what comes out of Paris, most will take place at the state, regional or city level,” said Libby Ferguson, state and regions director for UK nonprofit The Climate Group. On a local level, she said, “we’re already seeing some really substantial emissions cuts.”

December 13, 2015 (JUBA) – A South Sudanese civil society group (SSGC) has appealed to President Salva Kiir to consider another round of negotiations with political leaders to form the government of national unity.In a statement issued on Tuesday, the umbrella group, the Southern Peace and Security Council (SSGC) said it appreciated the efforts by "all concerned actors including the mediators".The statement added that the process was "a process and a political entity. Any decision made must be based on the will and wishes of the people and their leaders"."Therefore, we are concerned that the parties may decide to take unilateral actions to further extend the current term or may opt to give the transitional period a different flavour," the statement said, adding that "any action to be taken for the interim period must be guided by the wishes of the people and their leaders and by the need for stability in South Sudan".The SSGC stressed that "the leaders of the Sudanese people must ensure that it is within the legal framework and in accordance with the international law".On Sunday, the International Criminal Court (ICC) referred South Sudanese war crimes to the prosecutor for further investigation into possible crimes committed by the Sudanese army against the population.The ICC prosecutor's office referred the case to its chief prosecutor over allegations that the Sudan army committed serious crimes and crimes against humanity in the conflict in the country's Blue Nile State during June-October 2010 when the two parties agreed to form the new unity government.(

Thirty-five countries representing nearly half the world's population agreed to tougher nuclear security standards in a deal reached by a team of international experts.The countries signed off on the agreement after a week-long effort to resolve issues with what they say is an unworkable U.S. nuclear deal with Iran, which has already been hit by a unilateral U.S. withdrawal from the landmark accord.The experts came to an agreement with the nuclear watchdog’s nuclear watchdog that would require countries to take additional steps to verify that their nuclear programs are completely peaceful.Iran has long maintained its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.The new agreement will require the IAEA and other nuclear inspectors to verify that each country continues to carry out any necessary reprocessing and reprocessing, and that it will not undertake any additional work.Under the deal, countries will also be prohibited from reprocessing weapons-grade material.

Tokyo, Jul 11 (AP) The Japanese prime minister's push to revive nuclear power is facing a setback due to the lack of government approval after a nuclear-fuelled disaster at the Fukushima nuclear plant in the country's east.Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga had repeatedly said the country's nuclear power plants can be turned back on after a three-year cooling period.Also Read | India's External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar Meets US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington: LIVE Updates.The Fukushima disaster ended a multibillion-dollar Japanese government effort to restart nuclear power in Japan.Fukushima produced radioactive water that was then kept at a temporary storage facility in the Pacific and eventually spread to the sea.Also Read | US President Joe Biden Urges India to Stop Importing Iranian Crude: Report.Now, the issue of approval for the power plant is causing a political wrangle within Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, which Suga needs to maintain power in order to pursue plans for a new atomic power plant at the Hama nuclear plant in the western region.A three-year cooling period requires the approval of two-thirds of the members of the lower chamber of parliament. If the ruling coalition can get that, the plant can be turned back on.But that approval is still far from a consensus. Opposition parties are wary of getting their fingers pinched, a scenario that could trigger a no-confidence vote.Japan relies heavily on coal-fired electricity as its main source of electricity, which generates almost 80 per cent of the country's electricity and is cheaper than nuclear.

Afghan Taliban negotiators are meeting with U.S. officials in Qatar for a series of discussions aimed at building trust between the two sides ahead of the upcoming peace talks.Maulavi Qalamuddin, who once led the group's religious police, said Sunday the delegation includes several former officials, as well as a former secretary to the Taliban's leader, Mullah Omar.Qalamuddin said the talks include the possible release of Taliban prisoners from the U.S. military detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. He said the delegation traveled to Qatar from Pakistan - a possible sign that Islamabad might support the peace process.Meanwhile, Afghan officials said Sunday they will soon open a second front of negotiations with the Taliban, meeting in Saudi Arabia in an attempt to bring an end to the decade-long Afghan war.In Brussels Monday, NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said the alliance will adhere to its plans to withdraw combat troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2014.NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen talks during the presentation of NATO's Annual Report 2011at NATO headquarters in Brussels, January 26, 2012.Rasmussen said NATO expects the final transition of provinces and districts to lead Afghan responsibility by mid-2013.

NEW DELHI - The U.S. Ambassador to India has met Indian opposition leader Narendra Modi, ending a near decade-long boycott of the man who is the frontrunner to be India’s next prime minister. The Hindu nationalist leader was denied a U.S. visa in 2005 over his role in sectarian violence which swept his state in 2002. Television pictures showed U.S. Ambassador to India Nancy Powell and Bharatiya Janata Party leader Narendra Modi exchanging a cordial handshake before they sat down for discussions Thursday in Gandhinagar, the capital of Gujarat state headed by the Indian opposition leader. Political analysts said the handshake was prompted by the possibility that Modi could head India’s next government. He is the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition B.J.P., which polls show could dislodge the Congress party in upcoming national elections, to be held by May. The U.S. was among several countries which shunned the B.J.P. leader over allegations that he did not do enough to stop riots which swept through Gujarat in 2002 and killed nearly 1,000 people, mostly Muslims. Modi denies the accusations. The Supreme Court has found no evidence to prosecute him. As he grew in prominence on India’s national political stage in the last year, other countries and international bodies, including the European Union and Australia, restored ties with him. Former Indian ambassador to the United States Lalit Mansingh said the U.S. was bound to follow suit. “It would be quite embarrassing for the Americans not to recognize a democratically elected leader.

PANAMA CITY - A Panamanian court has granted bail to the two founders of Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the Panama Papers scandal, in a case allegedly tied to a sprawling corruption scandal in Brazil.Following their February arrest on charges of money laundering, Jurgen Mossack and Ramon Fonseca each paid $500,000 Friday and will be set free soon, the attorney for the two lawyers, Guillermina McDonald, told Reuters.McDonald said the court ruled the two were not a flight risk because they had been cooperating with the investigation.Another lawyer from the firm, Edison Teano, was still being held, she said.FILE - Partner of the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca, Ramon Fonseca speaks during an interview at his office in Panama City,, April 7, 2016.Mossack Fonseca emerged from obscurity in April 2016 with the Panama Papers, millions of documents stolen from the firm and leaked to the media that illustrated how the wealthy use offshore corporations to avoid taxes.
Japan’s new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga says he has spoken with Myanmar’s top military commander and can talk to him.

Participants at the Cannes Film Festival will be given fliers warning "Proper Behavior Required" as part of an anti-sexual harassment campaign at the May 8-19 event.The top women's rights official for the French government announced Friday that she reached a deal with Cannes organizers for the campaign.

U.S. CongressCongress Condemns Treatment of POWs in Iraq - 2002-04-10Statement of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on Resolution 1684 condemning the treatment of American prisoners held in Iraq since March 2003.Senate Resolution 1684Senator Patrick J. Leahy (D-VT) moved to censure Resolution 1684 (S. Res. 1684), which expresses condemnation of the treatment of American prisoners in Iraq since March 2003.Mr. Leahy explained that in Iraq since March 2003, 1,959 prisoners had been held, many of them for more than five years without any charges, without trial, and without even the possibility of release, except as a token act to prove that they are American. More than 1,100 prisoners were held longer than 10 months, including many for many years.In one case, the prisoner was held for over seven years, and died in March 2003, when Iraqi authorities recognized that the prisoner was a U.S. citizen. At the same time, the prisoner's mother was denied his right to claim compensation under a law created to provide compensation to U.S. prisoners held in Germany after World War I.Mr. Leahy added that while there has been some improvement in Iraq in terms of prisoner treatment and freedom of the press, there are still too many problems. He said that since the first detainee has been released, there have been at least five more detained American prisoners.Mr. Leahy said that he believes there is still time to make fundamental improvements to the treatment of POWs and prisoners of war. He said that he intends to hold a bipartisan hearing in the Senate as soon as possible to address these concerns.

CAPITOL HILL - Testifying before a Senate panel, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday declined to divulge details of President Donald Trump's private meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki last week, but declared the United States does not recognize Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea."Presidents are entitled to have private meetings. … I think it was more than appropriate that President Trump meet with Vladimir Putin," Pompeo said in the first Capitol Hill appearance by a member of Trump's national security team since the Helsinki summit, at which the president questioned U.S. intelligence on Russian election meddling.FILE - U.S. President Donald Trump and Russia's President Vladimir Putin shake hands after their joint news conference in the Presidential Palace in Helsinki, Finland, July 16, 2018.Trump later sought to clarify his position on Russian interference. Pompeo told lawmakers the president was absolutely clear on Russia's actions in the 2016 U.S. presidential election."He [Trump] has a complete and proper understanding of what happened. I know — I briefed him on it for over a year," the secretary of state and former CIA director said after listing steps the administration had taken to counter Russia, from imposing sanctions to sending military aid to Ukraine."The United States does not and will not recognize the Kremlin's purported annexation of Crimea," Pompeo stressed, adding that economic sanctions against Moscow would remain "until Ukraine's territorial integrity is restored."Moments earlier, the White House announced that a planned second Trump-Putin summit in the United States would not occur until 2019.

in VenezuelaWASHINGTON - America's top diplomat in charge of Venezuelan affairs is bolstering security at the U.S. embassy in Caracas after the government there began using military force and arresting prominent figures in opposition circles.Secretary of State Mike Pompeo arrived in Caracas on Tuesday to meet with Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza as the Trump administration pushes for the restoration of diplomatic relations between the two countries, a move that would also help lift a U.S. travel ban on a Venezuelan-American businessman.Pompeo, a former congressman who led Congress's congressional inquiry into alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, acknowledged that the embassy is in danger of being "an early target" for militants."We continue to have concerns about these acts of violence and we've got to take care when we move U.S. diplomats around that these events don't happen again," Pompeo said. "That's the work we've got to continue."Earlier this month, Venezuelan authorities said they had detained eight top opposition figures and others under investigation, including former deputy mayor of Caracas Antonio Ledezma and Jose Alfredo Pérez Rubi, an opposition leader who heads a Caracas-based group that helped organize a "militant" group that clashed with government troops last week. The government said the activists and their supporters were planning a failed coup.On Monday, Ledezma's lawyer, Julio Borges, said that his client was still being held by authorities in Caracas, though that led to the suspension of the extradition proceedings the State Department had long said it was pursuing. Ledezma, along with some opposition figures and other alleged coup plotters, were the subject of a May 8 report in the Miami Herald based on a leaked government document that described Ledezma's arrest and called for his release, an arrest that the U.S. embassy in Caracas said at the time was "unacceptable."Pompeo's announcement Tuesday that Ledezma would be sent back to the U.S. for a possible trial was a welcome step. But for Pompeo to meet with Arreaza on the same day was especially unusual. It's not clear what prompted Arreaza to meet with the secretary of state, as some reports suggested."

TAIPEI - A tiny group of islands in the East China Sea has shaped up as a flashpoint between Beijing and Tokyo. But smaller and diplomatically isolated Taiwan also claims the disputed Senkaku archipelago, which it calls the Diaoyutai. In Taipei, authorities have shied away from confrontation, while seeking to play a larger role in resolving the conflict. On Tuesday, Taiwanese officials urged Japan and China to back down from a conflict about the Senkaku islets, some 220 kilometers from Taiwan.Taiwan wants Japan to resume talks, after 16 earlier rounds, on fishing rights in waters near the uninhabited islets. Taiwan also asked the other claimants to consider Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou’s proposal for setting aside their territorial disputes to explore jointly for resources. Foreign Minister Timothy Yang told a news conference in Taipei that he is worried that the conflict will spiral. He says it is easy to escalate a conflict and harder to make peace. But Yang calls Taiwan a peacemaker for the international community and says that, in face of the East China Sea developments, the president has formulated a peace initiative. He adds that Ma is urging all sides to restrain themselves, set aside disputes, solve conflicts in a peaceful way and develop East China Sea resources together. The minister’s words reflect what analysts call the government’s underlying motives for seeking a broader role in the dispute. When President Ma took office in 2008, he said that despite diplomatic isolation Taiwan would try for more informal participation in international affairs.

Thousands of Parisians frustrated by continuous traffic jams and horrible commuting problems marched through the French capital Sunday, demanding an end to a nationwide rail workers' strike now entering its sixth day Monday.Many of the demonstrators said subway and commuter-train workers should return to work because they already enjoy privileges held by only a few other workers in France.Rail unions told their members to stay off the job today, but agreed to hold talks with managers of the state-run rail company on Wednesday.

- WNKY.com | Louisville News, Weather and SportsA Nigerian militant group has released nearly 900 kidnapped children as part of a massive amnesty program.Islamic Republic of Nigeria Boko Haram has released most of the 900 schoolchildren it has seized, an aid group says.The children were freed in the largest amnesty granted to hostages held by the group.The release comes in the face of growing criticism of Boko Haram's activities.In a statement on Wednesday, the group said it had released nearly 900 of the children it had kept in captivity over the past 18 months.The children were released "in order to serve the betterment and the education of the whole human family," the militants' Amadou Bakassi faction said.In exchange, the group said it would release several hundred hostages it has kept since last year."We call on the military and the authorities to end this brutal conflict so that all the people of this great and magnificent nation will be safe," the militants' statement said.No date was given for when the mass release will take place.The release comes at a time when Nigeria's army has been battling rebels in the north, while neighboring countries are concerned that the country's security is not improving.Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

World number one Maria Sharapova has been given a two-year suspension from competition for failing a drugs test.The 30-year-old failed to provide a sample on January 28, 2016, ahead of the Australian Open.Sharapova is now banned from the sport for two years."I accept the decision from the World Tennis Association and I apologise to my fans, my team and the sport for this error. I will accept the punishment for which I was sanctioned by WADA," said Sharapova.The athlete was not in court as she received her punishment, but the WTA announced that she had been handed the ban."This is the outcome of the independent anti-doping process initiated by WADA on 26 February 2017," said the statement.Sharapova was fined $10,000 and told to undertake 30 days of in-conceted therapy and a fitness assessment.This year's Australian Open is already in the books, but she did not participate in the first round with a sore shoulder.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Thursday that the number of sexual harassment complaints workers filed with the agency over the past year rose for the first time in nearly a decade. It attributed the increase to the #MeToo movement.The commission said the number of complaints, known as charges, filed in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 rose more than 12 percent over the previous year, when it received about 6,700. It said the numbers were preliminary, as the agency typically publishes comprehensive data from its fiscal year by the following February.EEOC Acting Chair Victoria Lipnic said in a statement that the numbers reflected "the heightened demand of the #MeToo movement."The #MeToo movement emerged in response to accusations of sexual harassment and abuse by powerful men in the entertainment industry starting last October. Many lawyers and other experts had predicted that the movement would spur an uptick in harassment claims.The number of sexual harassment charges lodged with the EEOC had fallen each year since 2010, when nearly 8,000 were filed.Many worker advocates and women's rights groups, as well as the commission in a 2016 report, said the decline was most likely the result of victims' decisions not to report harassment, rather than employers' efforts to effectively address it.In order to sue employers for harassment, workers must first file charges with the EEOC, which enforces federal laws banning workplace discrimination based on sex and other factors.

MANILA, PHILIPPINES - Filipino fans remembering boxing legend Muhammad Ali gathered near the site of his epic "Thrilla in Manila" fight with Joe Frazier for an art and photo tribute Friday.The display near Araneta Coliseum at Ali Mall was launched hours before Ali's burial in the United States. Ali died June 3 at age 74.Outside the coliseum, a cutout picture of Ali stands in a boxing ring. Fans crowded around a screen playing videos of the 1975 match that put the Philippines on the map. At the mall, memorabilia including boxing gloves with Ali's autograph, an original souvenir program and a gold commemorative coin also are on display.The Oct. 1, 1975, heavyweight championship, one of the greatest boxing matches in history, was won by Ali on a technical knockout at the jam-packed coliseum in Manila's suburban Quezon city and was watched by a worldwide audience.Filipino fans look at the memorabilia of the Oct. 1, 1975 "Thrilla in Manila" World Heavyweight boxing fight between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at the launch of an exhibit at The Ali Mall in suburban Quezon city northeast of Manila, Philippines Friday, June 10, 2016.Some facts about the fight:— It was the third fight between Ali and Frazier, his most bitter rival. The boxers had split the first two bouts, neither of which compared to the grueling rubber match.

Former president Olusegun Obasanjo may have received some much-needed good news after his alleged role in the $30 million bribe being shared by a former senator, Adeyemi Dipe.The former military dictator and his supporters have long campaigned for a return to the good old days. They have in fact been campaigning for his death.But while they still don't get it, the Nigerians have embraced this latest effort by the EFCC to look deep into their leader's past.The first to welcome it was Adeyemi Dipe himself.Obasanjo is Nigeria's greatest former leaderThe controversial ex-president and his supporters have always cried foul over his many years in power. And some still do.But the last few years have seen some new developments that have shown why he could no longer be a troublemaker.For one, he is no longer a divisive force.When the anti-corruption agency accused him of taking $300m bribe to deliver electoral materials in 2015, many people argued that he may have done the same thing today.But the EFCC's latest claims show that it is wrong.It does not seem any politician will be immune to any EFCC scrutinyThe latest move is a welcome one for Dipe and his allies.Even the current presidential candidate of the major opposition party is also said to have been investigated by the commission, according to reports coming out of the United States.But there is one thing that is certain; the Nigerians have all seen Obasanjo in their faces.Most of the politicians have been forced to take a turn against him and make the anti-corruption effort count.It is no longer about what he was alleged to have done in the past. It is about what has been alleged to be done today.When a leader who has won the respect of millions of Nigerians is investigated by the EFCC, there is no room for doubt. And they all know the truth.Obasanjo's many years of anti-corruption efforts have been widely praised.But a man who is accused of taking a $30 million bribe to deliver election materials may have been the greatest politician the country ever produced.And as long as he is not found guilty of the charges leveled against him, he can continue his hardline anti-corruption crusade.

The government of Turkey is once again coming under attack by religious and anti-religious forces. A recent report has revealed that the Education Ministry of the nation is considering plans for an Islamic school in the country. According to reports, the school would be funded from foreign and would cater to the education of the children of the Turkish-Turkish community.A report on the plans for an Islamic school was released by the National Security Committee, which is controlled by Turkey’s Supreme Military Council. The committee was said to be in charge of monitoring the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities, which includes its presence in Turkey.The report states that the plans for the school have been submitted to the Education Ministry and that the ministry has not accepted them.The plans were initially submitted in 2013 by a committee headed by the education minister, but the ministry never approved them. According to the report, the ministry is still considering the plans.The report states that Turkey does not follow Islamic laws and has many cultural laws that are separate from Islam. Therefore, the country follows different rules and laws than it does the religion of Islam.The report also said that a law, which calls for the expulsion of all students from religious schools, was submitted to the education ministry in 2011. The law states that there has to be an increase in the proportion of students from religious backgrounds in private schools.Turkish law states that all religious schools in the country have to comply with the standards of the Turkish education system, which is also an Islamic system. According to the report, the bill was submitted to the Supreme Military Council, and it was not approved.A recent report by the International Crisis Group states that Turkey’s government is being attacked again and this time it is the Education Ministry that is coming under attack.The country is coming under attack once again. This time the secularist education system is under attack. The country’s Education Ministry is coming under fire once again because the ministry is considering plans to fund an Islamic school.In recent years, the country’s Education Ministry is coming under fire for not only not following religious schools but also being the first to take steps to establish Islamic schools in Turkey.According to a report from the International Crisis Group’s Turkey branch, a new bill has been submitted to the Education Ministry. According to the report, the bill has been sent to the Supreme Military Council.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - A North Carolina college student slain while confronting a gunman in his classroom was expected to receive a hero's send-off Thursday as his body is taken back to his hometown with a police escort.Riley Howell's body was scheduled to depart from a Charlotte funeral home Thursday morning en route to Waynesville in the western part of the state.Meanwhile, the suspect accused of killing Howell and another student at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, while wounding four others, was due to appear in the afternoon to face charges including murder and attempted murder.Howell died in his classroom Tuesday, charging and tackling the suspect who opened fire with a legally obtained pistol, authorities said.Howell's decision to fight for the lives of others fit his character, said his friend David Belnap, who attended a candlelight vigil Wednesday with a homemade T-shirt with “Riley Howell is a hero” written on the back.“It seems very much like something he would do. I want that to be his legacy, that he lost his life to protect those he cared about,” the sophomore said about his friend.Howell, 21, likely went through the same active shooter drills as countless other students of his generation.

A top United Nations official says drug traffickers are using a more sophisticated system to smuggle drugs from West Africa to Europe.Alexander Schmidt, the West African head of the U.N. Office on Drug Crime, says the amount of cocaine seized in western Africa has gone down, suggesting that smugglers are repositioning drug routes and becoming increasingly sophisticated at hiding their operations.Schmidt says officials also believe cartels are using lightweight submarines similar to ones seen off the South American and the Caribbean coasts.Schmidt says although a few Latin Americans still dominate the trade, West Africans are starting to have increasingly influential roles.He places the value of the drugs passing through West Africa at $800 million.Schmidt spoke Monday at a meeting of the policy committee of the West Africa Coast Initiative.

(JNS) An Israeli archaeology team has stumbled on a rare, handwritten seal from the biblical king's "signs" for the Jewish people—a rare first since the discovery of the Jewish cuneiform writing.In 2015, the Israel Antiquities Authority (IAA) announced it had unearthed evidence of King Solomon's seal. The IAA said it had found a fragment of seal, which "is not only unique for the king but for the entire period of Jewish history."A senior IAA archaeologist said the rare seal shows that Solomon's seal "is very similar to other seals we have already seen." One expert said the seal "is among the most remarkable of the seals found in the period of writing in Israel."In a study to be published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences on Wednesday, the Israel Antiquities Authority archaeologists said they had identified the "signs" on the seal—which the expert said "could be the first of its kind for the entire period of the Hebrew language."The seal shows a pair of arrows in the air in front of the king. Two more arrows are seen in a circle. In another section, two lines of archers are seen in front of the king. In another section, the archers are in a line in front of the king and a circle in the direction of the direction of the archers. The archaic seal's text is also similar to a "sign in the land," which are common in Jewish sources like the Hebrew Bible.The study said researchers found the seal at a location not far from the archaeological discoveries made of the "golden cuneiform letters" at Kibbutz Arad. (See JNS report: Israel Sees First First Letter From Ancient World.)Archaeologists had previously unearthed one of the "golden cuneiform letters" on a hill near the same spot where the "signs" were found.Israeli researchers said that the area they discovered was within a "biblical landscape" of what they called "the biblical lands."

SANTIAGO - The Chilean public prosecutor's office has summoned the archbishop of Santiago to testify in an investigation into the alleged cover-up of child sexual abuse by members of the Catholic Church, the archbishopric said on Tuesday. The Santiago archbishopric said in a statement that Ricardo Ezzati had been summoned to speak with prosecutors on August 21 as a defendant accused of concealment. Prosecutors investigating criminal accusations against bishops, clerics and lay workers in the Roman Catholic Church in Chile are also probing claims that Ezzati and others covered up a network of 14 priests who systematically abused minors. Ezzati denied wrongdoing and vowed to cooperate with authorities. "I reiterate my commitment and the commitment of Santiago's Church to the victims," Ezzati said in the statement by his office. "I have the conviction that I never covered up or obstructed justice, and as a citizen will fulfill my duty to contribute all the information that may help clarify the facts." Last month police seized documents from the ecclesiastical court of the diocese of Santiago. The child sex abuse crisis has gripped Chile's Catholic Church since 2011, when Chilean priest Fernando Karadima was found guilty by the Vatican of abusing children in the 1970s and 1980s. Juan Carlos Cruz, one of Karadima's victims, said on Twitter that Ezzati has "little time left as archbishop of Santiago, but his new mission of answering for his cover-up, lies and other crimes ... has just begun."

LONDON - Details emerged Tuesday of the three London Bridge attackers: a Pakistan-born failed customer service clerk with links to one of Europe's most prolific hate preachers, a Moroccan pastry chef whose partner said he once went swimming rather than see his daughter and an Italian national who told authorities he "wanted to be a terrorist."At least two of the men were known to British intelligence and law enforcement officials, raising questions about whether anything could have been done to stop the attack, which began Saturday when the men drove a rented van into a crowd and then leaped out to stab people who crossed their paths. Seven were killed and nearly 50 wounded. All three of the attackers were shot dead by police.British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was fair to ask how the attackers "slipped through our net."Security has become a key issue in the run-up to Thursday's general election. British security officials said none of the men was considered violent, but they acknowledged the difficulty of predicting whether extremists will turn dangerous. The assault was the third attack in three months in which most of the assailants had been on authorities' radar at some point.As the investigation expanded to look at how the men knew one another and whether they were part of a larger conspiracy, Pakistani intelligence authorities swooped Tuesday into the town of Jhelum, where Khurum Butt lived until the time he was 7, when he moved to Britain. His cousin, 18-year-old Bilal Dar, told The Associated Press that Butt's uncle was taken in for questioning. It was unclear if he was detained."Our family is hurt by what he did," Dar said in the town about two hours east of Pakistan's capital.
