(@ChaudhryMAli88)DAMASCUS, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News / WAM - 27th Jun, 2019) The United Arab Emirates (UAE) does not intend to make war with its key ally, Eritrea, and will only seek to achieve its mutual objectives, President of the UAE Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum said.During the opening session of the General Assembly's 75th session in New York, the UAE Vice-President and Prime Minister Sheikh Mohamed said the country is fully committed to "the principles of the Charter of the United Nations" in addition to the international obligations that underpin its national sovereignty and territorial integrity."We must continue to ensure the security of our region and its peoples, and we can achieve this by supporting our partners and allies, the peoples of the world, to pursue our shared values and interests through peace, cooperation and integration," the UAE's leader added.He said the UAE has committed to a comprehensive foreign policy, a policy that upholds international rules, and respects and enhances the rights and freedoms of its people.As he outlined the UAE's vision for the coming few years, the head of state praised the positive changes in the region, particularly in Libya, Syria, Yemen, Somalia and other countries, stressing the importance of supporting peace and stability through all means."

, Says ICC ReportThe International Cricket Council (ICC) on Friday released a report that has threatened cricket's world governing body with sanctions if the players continue to ignore the Covid-19 guidelines. The ICC report said that a number of players and support staff in the domestic set-ups of the Test and ODI countries are either unwilling or unable to comply with the protocols.The report said that in some instances, players have not been able to meet the support staff in person, as the support staff are limited to one-on-one interaction with the players. While the Test players have to remain in isolation in a hotel room while the ODI players have to stay in single rooms while staying on the ground.The players have also not been able to maintain physical distance from each other.The report mentioned that there is a lack of cooperation between the teams and the players themselves about the use of the Covid-19 protocols.The report said that the players have been unable to adapt to the Covid-19 protocols and have continued to break them by playing each other's matches."These actions have, in some instances, put players at immediate risk," said the report.It also mentioned that the players' behaviour has not helped in creating a good atmosphere at the nets for the teams. The ICC chief executive Manu Sawhney has had a number of meetings with the players but it is reported that players still fail to follow the Covid-19 protocols and the ICC is left with no other option but to impose sanctions.The ICC report said that there are some areas in which some of the players can do well to improve their behaviour. For example, some players have to adhere to the Covid-19 protocols even when they feel they are not being treated fairly. The ICC further urged the players to take care of their families, especially their elderly parents, and to ensure proper diet in their respective homes.The ICC chief executive also suggested that players could start getting back to playing the T20 games to help the team achieve its target of the World Cup 2022.

: US LawmakersJulian Assange, President of WikiLeaks, speaks to media on Tuesday, Jan. 30, 2018 at the Ecuador Embassy, in London. (Photo: Yulia Soudova)Australian legislators on Friday criticized Washington for not providing consular assistance to Wikileaks' top editor, Julian Assange. The U.S. State Department has provided a "short" statement by Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs Bill Burns about Assange's request.The United States will consider "a range of options to help protect the health of Mr. Assange," Burns said in an initial statement, according to the New York Times.Assange, according to U.S. officials, is "at risk" from being extradited to the U.S. to face espionage charges over allegations he conspired to break into the Pentagon's computer networks in 2010 by taking a diplomatic cable and publishing it online. The U.S. government has charged Assange with espionage, accusing him of interfering in the U.S. political process.British lawmakers welcomed the statement from the U.S. government, but called for assistance to Assange."The government of Australia, along with a growing number of other countries, should call on the United States of America to explain why the Australian government is being dragged into a dispute in which the United States is not even a party and there is no legal basis for it," Michael Josephson, a member of the Australian Parliament, said in a statement to Reuters.While Australia's foreign minister and a senator from Britain also called on the U.S. government to provide consular assistance to Assange, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the United States is in no hurry to provide it."We have never provided it. We can do that now. We have it, we're not afraid," Pompeo told reporters at the State Department on Friday. "The British, we're with them. We're not afraid. We are very aware of what the issue is, we're not going to be dragged into it."On Tuesday, Pompeo told the BBC that he and his counterpart for the Department of State, Stephen Biegun, both traveled to Ecuador's embassy in London to request the information the country wanted, but that "the United States would not be rushed into providing what the United Kingdom is demanding."

Myanmar has established a commission of inquiry to probe allegations of human rights abuses in conflict-torn Rakhine state, authorities said Monday, as the country faces growing calls for accountability over accusations of ethnic cleansing against Rohingya Muslims.The four-person commission will be comprised of two local and two international members — Filipino diplomat Rosario Manalo and Kenzo Oshima, Japan's former ambassador to the U.N. — the Myanmar President's Office said in a statement. Manalo, 82, a former undersecretary of foreign affairs, will chair the commission.The two local members are lawyer Mya Thein and Aung Tun Thet, an economist and former UN official. Aung Tun Thet was last year appointed by de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi to a key role in Myanmar's response to the Rakhine crisis, and in April told a Bangladesh newspaper that Myanmar had "no intention of ethnic cleansing.""

MADRID - Spain heads to the polls Sunday for its most divisive and open-ended election in decades, set to result in a fragmented parliament in which the far-right will get a sizeable presence for the first time since the country’s return to democracy.After a tense campaign dominated by emotive issues, notably national identity and gender equality, the likelihood that any coalition deal will take weeks or months to be brokered will feed into a broader mood of political uncertainty across Europe.At least five parties from across the political spectrum have a chance of being in government and they could struggle to agree on a deal between them, meaning a repeat election is one of several possible outcomes.A few things are clear, however, based on opinion polls and conversations with party insiders. No single party will get a majority; the Socialist party of outgoing Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is leading the race; and there will be lawmakers from the far-right Vox party.Beyond that, the result is too close to call.Spanish Prime Minister and Socialist Party candidate Pedro Sanchez, center, smiles for a photo during an election campaign event in Toledo, central Spain, April 26, 2019. What undecided voters do in this tight race will shape the fortunes of the two political blocs that loosely took shape during campaigning that ended Friday.?

- Daily TrustNigeria has recorded a reduction in the number of cholera cases and a reduction in deaths from the disease.Nigeria, which has been battling some of the worst cholera outbreaks in recent times, has been trying to end the epidemics and has embarked on an aggressive clean-up.The Director General of Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), Chikwe Ihekweazu, said Tuesday in Abuja that 1,924 cases of the disease had been reported in 2019 and in 2018, 1,734 people were infected, making the country the country worst affected in Africa.Ihekweazu said the disease was under control in Lagos and Rivers States with 95 per cent population.He said the Agency recorded one death in the last 12 days, noting that the patient from the state was reported to have died from the disease.The director said about 20 per cent of the victims are children below five years of age, while about 12 per cent of cases are in Kano, Jigawa, Taraba, Bauchi and Gombe States.In the last 10 days, Ihekweazu said the Nigeria National Hospital in Bauchi had seen a significant number of the patients as compared to earlier in the year.He also said the Bauchi General Hospital had not recorded any new cholera case since December 2018.In Kano, where the disease has become rampant, the death toll has risen.Ihekweazu added that all the affected states had prepared the necessary facilities in terms of emergency response and support, and there was no need for panic.He said no case of the disease had been reported in the South-East, South-West, South-East Africa or the North-East geopolitical zone of the country."

to Kosovo StatusWashington, May 9 (IANS/PANA) Washington has thrown its full weight behind the EU's bid to bring a Nato membership bid to Bosnia's Bosnian Serbs, rejecting the opposition by the Serbian minority in Belgrade.US Defence Secretary James Mattis met with his Serbian counterpart Nikola Jankovic in Belgrade after meeting with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg.Stoltenberg, for his part, on Sunday visited Belgrade.During the meeting, Stoltenberg welcomed the US' readiness to offer financial and other support for the Bosnian Serb issue and the EU accession of Bosnia's Bosniaks.US officials did not provide details about financial assistance, but the US has offered to use US planes to fly troops to Bosnia's Serbs in case of need.The Serbian minority is opposed to the EU integration of Bosniaks, who want the same recognition as the Bosniaks of Bosnia's Serbs."We consider the [Bosnian] Serbs to be the people of the bosniak nation, not a minority that wants independence," US Defence Undersecretary James Scully said at the meeting, according to the Serbian daily Vecer."It is not about us, but about the international community. We are working toward a lasting solution. We are on the same page about a stable solution to this problem," Scully told Vecer.The US and Nato, as part of their efforts, are also trying to persuade the Serbs to join the EU accession process.During the meeting, Jankovic reaffirmed Belgrade's commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina's political and economic stability.Bosnian Serbs are under strict international sanctions.

The Gibson Brothers, with bandleader and vocalist J.D. Gibson, have released "Love Is Just What It Is," a follow-up to the group's 2019 album, "True Blue." The new release features four new songs.The Gibson Brothers have made quite a name for themselves as musicians, songwriters, and, as of 2018, recording artists. With just two albums behind them, "True Blue" earned a No. 1 spot on the Americana music charts, and now they have their eyes on a fourth No. 1 with "Love Is Just What It Is."The album was recorded at the legendary Mountain Top Studios in Muscle Shoals, Alabama. It was produced by Jason Isbell (brother of country music legend Willie), along with Jody Gibson and Ben Gibson.From the first notes of the album's title track, "Love Is Just What It Is," it is clear that the band has crafted a song as personal as its subject. This single is a moving tribute to the loss of his brother, who was killed in a traffic accident.With the new album, the Gibson Brothers have put the pedal to the metal and delivered a strong new song to their fanbase, as well as to those who have followed the band since its inception in 1996. "Love Is Just What It Is" is a strong follow-up to their best-selling album, "True Blue."The four-piece group consists of J.D. Gibson on vocals, Ben Gibson on guitar, Ben Gibson on bass, and J.D. Gibson on lead and backup vocals. The original line-up of Ben and J.D. Gibson formed in 2002 as the Gibson Brothers, and they have shared the stage with artists such as Eric Clapton, John Mellencamp, and Paul Simon.At the same time, J.D. Gibson's songwriting and music business talents are at the forefront of the music industry. In 2007, he produced and mixed the album of the same name for country music legend Tim McGraw, "Tim McGraw." And in 2011, Gibson's production team and band (the Gipson Brothers) won a Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration.J.D. Gibson's songwriting has also garnered him awards, both for the Gipson Brothers, and for himself. His song "I Tried to Keep Her Safe" earned a nomination for a Grammy Award in 2019.

Once again, thunderstorms have forced a delay for the launch of the U.S. space shuttle Endeavour.It is the second evening in a row that NASA has canceled the liftoff due to weather. The latest postponement Monday comes after two abortive attempts last month because of hydrogen fuel leaks.The space agency has until Tuesday or Wednesday to get Endeavour into orbit and up to the International Space Station. Otherwise, flight managers have to wait until near the end of July to make way for a Russian supply ship to launch and dock at the station.The seven-member shuttle crew plans to conduct a two-week mission to deliver the final piece of a Japanese laboratory known as Kibo. Kibo means "hope" in Japanese.Kibo amounts to a porch to be installed on the space station. It is designed to expose experiments to the vacuum of space.Endeavour will carry astronaut Timothy Kopra to take the place of Japan's Koichi Wakata, who has been on the space station since March.

's FuturePresident Joe Biden is facing growing criticism for his handling of the Afghan war. Biden has pledged to bring Americans and allies out of the country after a US exit, but many see Biden's plan as too risky and are upset that they aren’t being consulted on it.Some see Biden’s handling of Afghanistan as a failure. Some see a failure of intelligence. Others say the administration had a plan but didn’t execute it well. It’s been more than 100 days since the US invasion and many Afghans continue to fight to stay in their country.Biden’s top national security adviser Jake Sullivan said on August 31 the plan to leave Afghanistan had been put in place, but the details weren’t yet clear. Biden said at the time that he needed “a little more time” to process the plan, but that didn’t stop Biden from announcing the exit by September 11.President Joe Biden has faced calls for his resignation after his decision to pull US forces out of Afghanistan. After the Taliban’s stunning victory in Kabul on August 15, calls for the president to resign grew louder.When it comes to his administration’s handling of the withdrawal, Biden is taking some heat on both sides.Sullivan said there was a time when they would have left. The United States is at a crossroads, Sullivan said, and it’s a moment when we should make sure our allies can come out safely. Biden’s decision about the future of Afghanistan has not gone unnoticed at home, where some Republicans are calling for him to resign.Here is a sample of the reaction from Twitter on August 28:Biden’s handling of the withdrawal from Afghanistan has already been condemned. Some Republicans are calling for Biden to resign after he decided not to evacuate Americans who risked their lives to fight alongside the Taliban.I can't breathe when I look at you. https://t.co/nJ6X6qxwSq — Tim Scott (@TimScottSC) August 27, 2021Biden made a big mistake by putting military on the ground in that country.

, Says GiulianiWhen Trump's lawyer said Trump and the National Enquirer had a relationship that goes beyond headlines from recent years, the lawyer for the President said he has more to say.David Cohen, a former New York City police officer and one-time Trump personal lawyer, told Reuters that he has "more to say" about the President's relationship with the tabloid."I have more to say about that," he said after a news conference outside Trump's golf club in West Palm Beach, Florida. "It's a long, complicated story, and there are still more details."He declined to elaborate further, saying that he was not going to "play for the Enquirer."Cohen, who was Trump's personal lawyer from 2015 to 2017, has been cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller as part of the Russia investigation, according to the Justice Department's report on the matter.The Justice Department released a report Monday evening stating that Cohen had given false testimony to a Senate panel as part of its investigation into Russian election interference in the 2016 campaign.But the report also said Cohen had lied to Congress under oath.Copyright 2020 NPR. To see more, visit https://www.npr.org.

Disgraced Italian football club Juventus is appealing its punishment for match fixing to a civil court, and risks further sanctions from the Italian federation and the world governing body, FIFA.The Turin-based club was stripped of its last two Serie A titles, relegated to the second division, and docked 17 points for its part in a match fixing scandal.Juventus said the penalty was too severe and started the appeal process before the Lazio regional court near Rome. A Juventus spokesman said Thursday's action merely notified the court of the club's intention to appeal but is not the official documentation. A hearing is scheduled for September 6.The Italian Football Federation has threatened further sanctions for taking the matter to civil court, including deducting another three points.The Italian governing body acted after FIFA threatened to bar all Italian teams - including clubs and the World Cup-winning national team - from international competition.

KAFR KANDIL, Egypt - Official results from Egypt's historic presidential election are not expected until next week, but early speculation after the first two-day round is showing a race too close to call. The rural vote appears as divided as it is elsewhere.As Egyptians await the results of their first truly open presidential election, fault lines between Islamists and old guard secularists appear to cut across the nation. In the village of Kafr Kandil, south of Cairo, the choice plays well with the largely conservative rural vote: some seek stability in religion, others in past performance. Many of the latter look to veteran diplomat Amr Moussa, who along with former Air Force chief Ahmed Shafik, promises a return to pre-uprising law and order, minus the corruption. Outside the village school, which is serving as the village polling station, Shadia Ewis, a housewife and mother of five, hopes Moussa wins. She thinks he's a "respectable man" who "could control the country." Her friend and fellow housewife, Magda Hassan, agrees. She says she wants Moussa to institute reforms, so that it won't be like it was under the old government, when everything was exploited. Getting a fair shake from the government is a key concern of Islamist candidates' supporters, too. Farmer Ali Hassan Abdel Baki believes the best man for the job is the Muslim Brotherhood's Mohamed Morsi. Sitting in the bright sunshine, his fields of tomatoes and grains behind him, Abdel Baki says "there is unfinished business." He says a lot of people are out of work, and the next leader, "with God's help, will look after the poor."

JOHANNESBURG - As South Africa joins the rest of the world in commemorating World AIDS Day, experts say the country's women below age 25 have a high HIV infection rate and studies show they are getting the virus from older men.Lolobrigitha Tsupa, 30, was 23 when she learned she was HIV positive. She was looking for a man who could satisfy her craving for a fast and high-flying life. But Tsupa said she got more than that. "I met this man who had money, drove nice cars, and the man was very old, old enough to be my father. He would buy me things, gifts, and he would take me out," she said. "That is the life I wanted to live and I did not have that at home. Anyway, that is where I got the virus from."Tsupa’s story is similar to that of 28-year-old Brenda Masango. Masango said she discovered she was HIV positive in 2007, while still a student at the University of Tswane. She said it all started when her parents cut their financial support to punish her bad behavior. "I had to buy clothes for myself" and cover food costs at school, she said.

Chinese company explores a giant copper mine in Zimbabwe, a landlocked country of 20 million that depends heavily on foreign importsChinese mining firm Yushui plans to build a huge copper mine in Zimbabwe as well as another huge copper mine nearby. The Chinese mine will take up to 80 percent of the territory.But the villagers who live near the copper deposit in the Midlands Province say they have no interest in taking part in the Chinese mining projects. "Our village is already a very poor community. Our people are already suffering from a shortage of food as well as water," says Sanyange Tafiri.Yushui, in its application to the Zimbabwe authorities, argues that the village should accept a 10 percent stake in the new mine project. Yushui's chairman is a businessman who is also a senior figure in the Zanu-PF."If they fail to win acceptance here in the Midlands Province, they might find themselves facing political hurdles in their efforts to bring their projects to life," predicts Tafiri.Yushui will not be building the mines by itself. It will rely on the support of the Chinese Communist Party.Yushui is also constructing a 500-megawatt hydroelectric dam on the Zambezi River near the Zimbabwean town of Zvishavane.The dam has become an international symbol of economic progress in Africa and is now considered among China's most promising water projects.The Chinese company plans to generate 30 billion cubic meters of water for its factories, farms and hydropower stations using the massive Zimbabwe dam project as a reservoir.But local villagers say the Zambezi project will cut their river flow to a trickle. The Chinese company says it would increase water levels through pumping in the surrounding forest.China is also building two new dams on the Congo Basin in Africa. These mega projects would raise water levels and flood the Congo Basin for several years to help China expand its industrial heartlands.A number of Chinese companies have built large industrial projects in Africa. Last year, China's largest industrial company, China International Capital Corporation, built the 1,500-megawatt Tanzanian power plant, the largest single industrial plant in Africa.

Eleven people, including several journalists, have been killed in a brutal attack on a convoy of vehicles near the town of Raga in Western Bahr el Ghazal state in South Sudan, officials said Monday.Western Bahr el Ghazal Governor Rizik Zachariah Hassan called for flags to be flown at half-staff around the state for three days. He expressed his condolences to the families of the dead and vowed the state government will not stop working because of the attack.Newly appointed Raga County Commissioner Maradom James was among the four people wounded in the attack on Sunday.We were not expecting to survive... So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs.James' private secretary, Justin Abo Saleh, who was in the same car as the county commissioner, said the assault came out of the blue and was ferocious. He said the two vehicles came under a hail of bullets from both sides of the road.“We were not expecting to survive," he said. "We talked to our driver that he should not stop and already these people started firing on us. So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs."The car that Saleh and James were in was able to get away. After awhile, they returned to where the brutal assault had taken place and found a gruesome scene.The victims had been shot and then hacked to pieces before their bodies were set alight, Saleh said.

Dr. Greg Mills, National Director of the South African Institute of International Affairs, says the Middle East crisis has a great deal of relevance to South Africa and the rest of the continent. He says South Africa has Muslim and Jewish populations, while many other African countries have large Muslim populations, such as Nigeria and Sudan.He says Africa has an interest in the Middle East partly due to its own colonial past and developmental challenges. The crisis does, however, divert attention away from Africa.He says some African leaders could contribute to the Middle East peace process, such as Nelson Mandela. But he says those leaders are currently busy trying to bring peace in such places as Burundi, Angola and the DRC.He says the historical experience of Africa, especially South Africa, has lessons to offer to Israel and the Palestinians. Dr. Mills says there?

Chelsea Manning, the Army soldier convicted in 2013 of giving classified documents to WikiLeaks, launched an unconventional campaign for US Senate in New York on Tuesday, calling for a vote against Donald Trump's Republican running mate Mike Pence.Manning says his political platform was inspired by the Occupy Wall Street movement that first drew national attention in October 2011. He says he has decided to run as a Democratic candidate because the Democratic Party has "abandoned" him.Ahead of a live-streamed town hall meeting on Facebook on Wednesday, Manning, 29, was questioned on why he was using "a pseudonym" to identify himself on the internet."I feel as if if I were to run as a Democrat in the general election, it'd be easier for me to be the Democratic nominee than as myself," he said.Manning has been living in the Washington, DC area since she was found guilty of a series of charges related to the "Collateral Murder" video that released in 2010 showing the killing of two civilians in Baghdad's Nisur neighborhood.She said she does not feel shame about her conviction.She said she plans to serve her full sentence of 35 years, including a 20-year period under house arrest and then, if all goes well, parole. She says she has lost weight since the sentence.On Tuesday, she said she was looking forward to her first meeting with President Barack Obama on Wednesday, and believes that Obama will let her serve out her sentence.In an interview with Yahoo News after the meeting, Manning said she had decided to run after hearing Obama was considering a pardon. "He's my president, and he has my best interest at heart, and I believe I can do what he needs to do, or he will pardon me. The only thing I'm trying to say is that I'm trying to be fair to everyone," she said.Asked if the US government had an obligation to protect its citizens if they released classified information that endangered those living in countries whose governments might use the information in a terrorist attack, she answered, "I don't think there is any obligation. The same reason I did what I did, I just did it under different circumstances. I do not believe I am above the law."

On June 13, Turkish Constitutional Court upheld the HADEP decision passed last December. The ruling says that the PKK should be banned because the armed Kurdish movement is still engaged in the ongoing armed struggle and still uses "terrorists" as cover.Last year, Turkish Armed Forces (TSKF) carried out a military operation in the Syrian border regions in order to fight against PKK terrorist groups.During this operation, TSKF fighters were killed. The military operations were launched in Kobane and other regions in northern Turkey where the PKK operates.Although the PKK is still considered a terror organization by Turkey and its Western allies, it is also recognized by the Turkish government and TSKF soldiers as a part of the Syrian civil war.The PKK has been fighting for independence for a number of decades, and in northern Iraq the PKK's armed struggle is ongoing.

Iran has filed a lawsuit against the United States alleging that Washington's decision in May to impose sanctions after pulling out of a nuclear deal violates a 1955 treaty between the two countries, the International Court of Justice said Tuesday.A State Department official said the application was without merit and the United States would fight it in the court."While we cannot comment on the specifics, Iran's application is baseless and we intend to vigorously defend the United States before the ICJ," a State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters.President Donald Trump withdrew the United States from the 2015 nuclear pact with Iran reached by his predecessor Barack Obama and other world powers, and ordered tough U.S. sanctions on Tehran. Under the 2015 deal, which Trump sees as flawed, Iran reined in its disputed nuclear program under U.N. monitoring and won a removal of international sanctions in return.The ICJ, which is based in The Hague and is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations tribunal for resolving international disputes. Iran's filing asks the ICJ to order the United States to provisionally lift its sanctions ahead of more detailed arguments."

GENEVA - A new report by the Inter-Parliamentary Union finds that worldwide, members of parliament in Africa and Asia are at greater risk of intimidation, imprisonment, and other abuse than in other regions.The report says members of parliament are subject to multiple abuses, including death, torture, threats, arbitrary arrest and detention. The Inter-Parliamentary Union says its Committee on the Human Rights of Parliamentarians is investigating the cases of 311 MPs from 41 countries - a 13 percent increase over 2013.The data reveal 38 percent of the MPs who faced governmental abuse are from Africa, 25 percent from Asia, 18 percent from the Middle East and North Africa, 14 percent from the Americas and five percent from Europe.IPU human rights program manager Rogier Huizenga said the three worst cases in Africa were Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia and Eritrea. They represent 21.5 percent of abuse cases on the continent.“DRC - there are a number of serious cases where due process is a concern, where freedom of expression is a concern. Eritrea is the famous case of the G-11, the members of parliament who wrote a critical letter to the authorities, to the president, Afwerki, 2001, and were taken away in September that year and were never seen again. And, then the case in Zambia where there are concerns about the use of the Public Order Act and the limitations that that brings along for the right to freedom of assembly,” said Huizenga.In Asia, the IPU cites 78 MPs from 12 countries who are under threat.It singles out the Maldives as the worst violator.

BETHESDA, Md. (CN) – Two Native American teen boys who were pulled from their college basketball trip to the Bahamas said Thursday that they want new travel plans as well as a return of donations they received in the aftermath of the alleged abuse.“I did not really care where they were going,” one of the young men, known as T.J., told reporters Thursday at the Howard County Detention Center after spending the first night under house arrest in a Baltimore hotel.“At least I know I got to go to school,” T.J. said.T.J., now 16, and his friend, now 18, met members of the University of Washington's school sports administration at a local hotel last Tuesday. They were told the university was investigating alleged assaults by five University of Washington football players, and asked to be included in the investigation.T.J. said the allegations were "basically bullshit" but wanted to go with his football teammates to support them, according to court documents.The university quickly announced it was investigating the incident and said T.J. and his friend had not been involved."T.J. and I had no knowledge of the alleged assault prior to their arrival at the UW campus, nor are they involved in any way in any way in the conduct that has been reported to the University of Washington," coach Chris Petersen said in a statement.T.J. said he felt upset and scared but was able to sleep comfortably in his hotel room in Baltimore."I didn't know what was going on but I knew something bad happened," T.J. said.The two men were told to keep their cellphones on and were escorted to an SUV at around 2:30 a.m. Wednesday morning. They were told the men would be brought to the Nassau Airport at 4:30 a.m.T.J. said they left their hotel and were taken to the airport by the university for questioning."I don't know why," T.J. said. "They asked me the same questions they asked the rest of us but they didn't press the issue and they just walked away from us. They didn't say anything bad about T.J., or the situation."T.J. said he was taken to a police station in the same city in order to speak with an investigator."

's SonThe United Nations Security Council will next week investigate Pakistan's claims of the assassination of former Pakistani prime minister Yousuf Raza Gilani's son, Dr Tahir Mehmood Gilani.Mehloon, as the elder Gilani is popularly known, was killed in an unknown attack in eastern Afghanistan on August 27 last year, almost a year after his father's assassination.Pakistan has said that it has evidence to support the claim, while the United States has rejected the charge, saying the United Nations Security Council would be ill-equipped to properly investigate the matter and any other allegation related to the alleged killing.The US has accused Pakistan of being behind the attack and called for a full independent investigation, but Islamabad has repeatedly dismissed the allegation as fake.The UN Security Council will next week set up an international investigation commission to investigate the alleged killing of Gilani's son and then take a statement from Gilani, who is in exile in the United Arab Emirates.The UN would set up a separate committee to look into the death of Gilani's son, but that committee would not necessarily be in charge of the inquiry and it might consist of experts from elsewhere, such as France, to facilitate the investigation.

Chinese military vessels are now operating in the Northern Atlantic, and Russian submarines are prowling those same waters at a pace not seen since the end of the Cold War, the Navy’s top admiral told VOA in an exclusive interview.Chief of Naval Operations Adm. John Richardson said China's military movements from the North Atlantic into the Mediterranean Sea create a "new dynamic.""Even five years ago, we wouldn't have seen anything like this,” Richardson said.According to Richardson, the Chinese navy is a global one that is both "ready and capable" of operating wherever Beijing wants.“They're certainly a pacing competition for us in terms of the naval threat,” he told VOA.However, Chinese operations near the United States' eastern shore are not as threatening as Russian vessels lurking below the ocean’s surface. NATO allies from North America to Europe are increasingly concerned about the uptick of Russian submarine activity in the North Atlantic.“We're talking about more (activity) than we've seen in 25 years,” Richardson said.U.S. officials worry that Moscow may try to use its submarines to cut or tap into undersea cables that connect the two continents.Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, speaks to reporters at the Pentagon, July 27, 2018.

TAIPEI - Police clashed with hundreds of protesters in Taipei Monday after the group upset over a trade deal with China broke into the government’s chief office complex. As hundreds more remain camped out in Taiwan’s parliament, the government weighs what to do next. About 2,000 police officers expelled hundreds of protesters from Taiwan’s guarded cabinet offices before dawn on Monday. The government mobilized riot squads and water cannons to oust demonstrators in a five-hour struggle. Protesters want to stop quick approval of the trade deal, calling that approach risky as China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and wants political reunification. Lin Nan-hsin, a 20-year-old protester from a university in central Taiwan, was among those expelled by police. He said there are two camps of protesters, one that advocates peace and the other that prefers a more extreme form of protest as the only way of getting the government’s attention. Lin said that in the end, there was a discussion with the lead protest planners about whether to break into the cabinet complex and finally a go-ahead was given. Taiwan and China signed a service trade pact in June following several other trade and investment agreements reached since 2008.

The same survey shows many Venezuelans are also opposed to the constitution. They argue the document has been the cause of the political conflict in the country.According to a new poll, about 85 percent of Venezuelans want the Venezuelan Constitution Revision Committee to make changes to the document.The survey, conducted between November 9 and November 14, polled 4,000 people through an interactive digital tool that enables a voter to rank issues in a list.The document, which was written in 1983, is the fourth to the eighth in the country's 27-year constitution. However, it was ratified in 1994 and has been amended several times since.In 2011, a court ordered that some laws should not have been ratified, including a law on the country's Constitution.Some 70,000 protesters in Caracas in 2012 called for the government to remove certain articles of the constitution, which they argued were unconstitutional because they did not follow certain rules.Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, whose father was the president for 15 years before leaving in 1981, is seeking to replace the Constitution. He has repeatedly called for a referendum.But the country's Supreme Court has dismissed calls for a new referendum in the past, citing the nation's political crisis.Many Venezuelans feel that the constitution, which was ratified in 1974, has not been implemented well.Many blame the country's crisis, which includes high inflation, food shortages and rampant crime, on the document.Most also believe the country is heading for a civil war.This is not the first time an online poll has revealed Venezuelans' attitudes on the constitution.An online poll conducted by the government in November 2013 found that about 75 percent of Venezuelans believe the constitution is "unbalanced," while another 21 percent said it is "balanced."

With legislation overhauling taxes and health care on an uncertain path, President Donald Trump returned to the familiar. Trump brought 52 business leaders from New York City to the White House Tuesday to talk about another favorite campaign issue — infrastructure and economic growth. The U.S. economy has so far proven to be a point of pride for a presidency that has otherwise gotten off to a rocky start. Trump inherited a stable economy from former President Barack Obama, an economic recovery that's heading toward its eighth year. But Trump believes he can do more for business. Trump and several of his top aides emphasized plans to cut red tape and jumpstart infrastructure projects at Tuesday's meeting, while also previewing for the CEOs other priorities that include shortening flight times for airplanes, increasing the power grid's efficiency and targeting programs to improve job training. At one point the president had an aide come on stage to hold up a long scroll of the government's approval process for building a highway. The president then pledged to eliminate more than 90 percent of the regulations involved and "still have safety.'' He provided no details. The administration has committed to directing as much as $1 trillion for infrastructure over the next decade, although it has yet to release policy specifics. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao recently said she expects a plan will be unveiled later this year. But getting a measure through Congress could be difficult given the Republican majority in both chambers and their desire to reduce tax rates as much as possible.

ASUNCION - Security forces surrounded Paraguay's Congress on Tuesday while lawmakers argued over a possible change in law that would allow President Horacio Cartes to run for re-election, a move that the opposition says would weaken democratic institutions.A bill allowing presidents to run for a second five-year term was defeated in the legislature last year.This week a group of senators asked for a special session that the opposition interpreted as the start of a new campaign by Cartes and his coalition to enable presidential re-election.Paraguayans taking part in the “Long March” protest, a week-long walk from the interior to the capital, chant slogans against President Horacio Cartes, in Asuncion, Paraguay, Feb. 13, 2017.Opposition leaders and dissident members of Cartes' party accused him of shaking the country's democratic foundations by ordering that Congress be surrounded by police and soldiers.“We have to safeguard the republic,” said Senator Blanca Ovelar, a member of Cartes' Colorado Party who has broken with the president. “This is a situation of institutional breakdown.”Soft drink and tobacco mogul Cartes was elected to a five-year term in 2013. His strongest backers want him to be allowed to run for another term next year. Critics say a constitutional change aimed at benefiting a sitting president would be unfair.The Inter-American Development bank is holding a regional meeting in Asuncion starting on Thursday. Security consultancies International SOS and Control Risks issued a statement warning conference goers to avoid the vicinity of the Congress building in case tensions escalate.On Wednesday, thousands of subsistence farmers are expected to come to capital city Asuncion to lobby for agrarian reform.

, Climate ActionBRUSSELS – European Union leaders will on Wednesday push for an economic stimulus and climate actions after a chaotic summit that saw Germany abandon a push for a green plan, while French President Emmanuel Macron pushed for an emergency financial pact to provide support to his economy hit by the coronavirus pandemic.The EU leaders’ meeting – known as a summit – is held every three months as the EU grapples with the pandemic and the economic effects of the lockdowns and the lockdowns to slow the virus’ spread.The leaders will push for a stimulus package worth 1 trillion euros ($1.18 trillion), as well as climate actions, including a carbon trading system and the introduction of an annual carbon tax, at the EU summit, which was pushed back by seven days to Wednesday to give leaders more time to talk.Leaders will look at proposals that have been put forward by a special commission and other leaders but have been watered down or discarded.The EU leaders will seek consensus on the proposal for a Green Deal from German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron at the summit, sources familiar with the meeting told Reuters on Tuesday.“

In Kenya, sending money home to villages and farms from the city used to be problematic. Many people in rural areas do not have access to banking, making it difficult for them to receive and send money. But a revolutionary mobile telephone system is making it easy to move money, changing Kenyan society. The system was the first of its kind in the world.As Stephen Mbugua works on his farm a half-hour drive from the capital Nairobi, his mobile phone beeps. He is getting a text message saying that his son has sent the elderly farmer some money - through the mobile telephone.Mbugua is a customer of a service called MPESA, offered by a mobile phone company called Safaricom.People who wish to transfer money through their mobile phones can do so at locations across Kenya.And that is good news for Mbugua, who says the service saves him time and money. "I used to go to Nairobi or to any bank to pay my bills. But right now, since MPESA came, I do not go to Nairobi, I just pay my bill from here," he said.Phelister Omari, 22, who works in a hospital in Nairobi, is sending money to her mother. She fills out a form with the amount she wishes to send, plugs that amount into her telephone, and gives the clerk the amount plus extra for charges.People who are sent money go to the agent with their mobile phone, sign a form, and receive the cash.Omari says she appreciates the service. "It is very fast. The MPESA, they are available everywhere.

Venezuela’s chief prosecutor is seeking legal action against top Supreme Court justices for their actions during the government’s brutal crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.Venezuela’s Chief Prosecutor Tarek William Saab on Friday filed a complaint with the Supreme Court’s disciplinary commission accusing several of its members of usurpation of power, defamation, disobedience to their oath, the constitution and treason.“As Prosecutor of the Venezuela’s Law and order of the Judiciary I demand and declare from this platform and in the presence of these justices that you must immediately suspend and suspend until the conclusion of this prosecution the operation carried out on August 29 and 30, 2020,” Saab said in a video posted on Facebook that included footage of protests that erupted in the country in response to the decision to cut the monthly salary of teachers to a fraction of the cost.Venezuela’s constitutional court has not ruled on Saab’s request but his action could be the start of a more dramatic conflict within the government that could prove crucial in determining the future of the oil-rich nation.The action comes as opposition members of congress have rejected a motion by a parliamentary delegation to try and impeach five opposition-friendly Supreme Court justices, most of whom had overseen harsh anti-protest laws. Some said their action was retaliation for the decision of the top court to reduce the salary of teachers by half during one of the biggest waves of anti-government protests in the country’s history.The protesters chanted the term “el hombre al que esta perdido,” or “the man who fell asleep” in reference to the five Supreme Court justices.“I want you to understand this,” Venezuelan lawyer Edgar Zambrano said in video filmed by the prosecutor. “This is not a joke. You and your fellow magistrates were complicit in the killing of two people, in the face of international support. And you are asking that the president not be given the opportunity to investigate these crimes and hold the perpetrators accountable?”

A Papua New Guinea court has ruled Australia's detention of asylum seekers on its northern island of Manus is illegal.The court said Tuesday the detentions of the asylum seekers violates their constitutional right to personal liberty. It ordered the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea to take immediate steps to end the detention of more than 800 people at the facility.Under Australia's immigration law, anyone intercepted trying to reach its shores by boat is sent for processing to camps in Papua New Guinea and the island nation of Nauru.Australian Immigration Minister Peter Dutton said the ruling would not change Australia's policy of offshore detention. "No one who attempts to travel to Australia illegally by boat will settle in Australia," Dutton said."Those in the Manus Island Regional Processing Center found to be refugees are able to resettle in Papua New Guinea. Those found not to be refugees should return to their country of origin."Detention Camp Sites on Manus Island, Papua New GuineaHuman rights groups have long criticized Australia's asylum seeker policy, which the government says is aimed at protecting its borders and preventing dangerous ocean crossings in unsafe boats."

This is what happens when you do a lot of things that should be done and the more you do, the more time you spend trying to do it. After having had a stroke (I assume it happened during an "aftermath" of the stroke, at least in my case), I found myself struggling and looking for the time to do more.I didn't understand why this was so hard to do so I started to research and found out that when you do lots of things and you have a stroke, it is not as if you can just do all at once. It is necessary to do things gradually and do them in stages one at a time. A lot of things I had previously thought did not actually take place because they involved several things and I just never connected all the dots.If you have had a stroke and know for sure that you can't go to all the places you need to go or do all the things you need to do in one go, then you need to find someone who can help you to do the most difficult or time consuming things. It takes more than the amount of time you normally would be able to accomplish. In my case, I did need a lot of help to do the things I needed to do but the amount of time that had to be spent helped by the experience of having had a stroke. It is like being a child again. The more experiences that I had, the clearer and more comfortable I was with all of the problems and I was able to do more tasks to accomplish them.We do need to take the time to do a lot of things but that also means that the time we need to spend doing these things is not as long as before we had a stroke. The more experiences we have the more quickly we can adapt to changes and to the new challenges we face.A year after my stroke I was able to do many of the things I had been trying to do for months before.
Give us 5 minutes, and we'll give you the world. Around the clock, Voice of America keeps you in touch with the latest news.

WASHINGTON -- Director of Public Affairs for VOA Jim Harrington discusses the proposed new Burmese bureau and a meeting with the foreign minister of Burma.The U.S. Agency for International Development's new Burmese bureau will give the Agency a much-needed foothold in the region where it has so far struggled to get a foothold.Since Burma's return to democracy in 2008, there has been a lot of anticipation among U.S. and international aid organizations on when exactly the U.S. Agency for International Development would establish a base there. As I said in a December 2009 post (see it here), I've been thinking that if this could happen, it would create opportunities and a lot of leverage to get out the foreign aid dollars that have been invested in Burma so far. Now I've learned from the Burmese Ministry of Foreign Affairs that a new Burmese bureau was indeed being planned, and this is what I was told by officials in the U.S. administration.Here is what I was told. The new bureau was tentatively scheduled to open next summer. It will be a U.S.-funded facility, but will work closely with a Burmese-led development and reconstruction project already under way in the country.

BEIJING – A new scandal has revived memories of the tainted products that plagued China for years until the end of last year.Chinese companies are not buying, much to the dismay of the U.S. government and its allies who want to keep China in the international system, analysts said.More than 2 billion Chinese products have made headlines over the last year as Beijing tightened import controls and the company that makes them faced fines, bans, recalls and other disciplinary actions from the government.In one of the biggest scandals in years for China, state prosecutors said they are investigating tainted products from seven companies and were in search of hundreds more.In January this year, an official from an electronics company in central China’s Hubei province said a tainted-product scandal that had plagued her firm was a “common occurrence,” according to news reports and government documents.The official blamed the incidents on local producers who “don’t do things correctly or they might mess up.”

China rejected a proposed U.S.-China declaration over North Korea's nuclear program as a meaningless gesture and an attempt to pressure North Korea's government into abandoning a nuclear weapons program, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang said on Wednesday.China was the only country to attend the latest round of talks between U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and his North Korea counterpart, Foreign Minister Yun Song-ho, who met Tuesday in New York in the second phase of the United Nations General Assembly."The U.S. and China have never agreed to the so-called U.N. Security Council's sanctions imposed in the name of the Security Council, and have never agreed to the U.N. resolution adopted on its own," Lu said at a regular news briefing.Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and Foreign Minister Wang Yi attended the first round of meetings on North Korea in New York on Monday. Li's U.S. counterpart told the General Assembly that his country wants a negotiated solution to the North Korea crisis and the international community is ready to support any such proposal.Lu rejected the U.S. offer and said China would not abandon efforts to resolve the nuclear issue based on mutual interest.

Police in Moyale have started dispersing hundreds of people protesting against the arrest of Oromo People’s Congress (OPC) chairman Gizak Eri and his associates by the Oromo Regional Police Commander (PRO).The Oromo People’s Congress has accused police of using brutal tactics during the arrest.“We are in conflict with the state, we cannot submit ourselves to the state, we will continue to protest until we see justice,” said Lisi Abdi, OPC’s regional leader.“We also reject the security force and call on our leaders not to cooperate,” he added.Abdi said police had been brutalizing Oromos.“Every time Oromo people are arrested, their hands are tied with an ankle,” he said.Abdi called on Oromo elders in the region to call the violence directed against the Oromo by the police.“The entire people in the region has shown solidarity,” he said.“We will not stop,” he added.“Police will be held accountable.

WARSAW - Poland has signed a long-term deal with a U.S. company for supplies of liquefied natural gas as part of an effort to reduce its dependence on Russian energy, the two sides announced on Wednesday.Port Arthur LNG, a subsidiary of San Diego-based Sempra Energy, and Poland’s state gas company PGNiG jointly announced the agreement for the sale of 2.7 billion cubic meters per year of gas to Poland over a 20-year period.Their statement said that is enough to meet about 15 percent of Poland’s daily gas needs.“This agreement marks an important step toward Poland’s energy independence and security,” the U.S. Secretary of Energy Rick Perry said.Sempra Energy’s CEO Jeffrey Martin said the deal helps his company “advance our vision to become North America’s premier energy infrastructure company.”

The Occupy Wall Street movement is once again seeking a physical presence in New York City, following its dispersal by police from a lower Manhattan park in November. Our correspondent reports the attempt renews tensions between protesters and law enforcement.?This is god**** our park! This is our park! The real people?s park! It?s a real public park," screamed a protester.This impassioned Occupy Wall Street protester recently denounced New York police as bullies for enforcing a regulation that limits the size of signs in public parks. At issue was this long banner. Protesters say the regulation applies to commercial vendors, not public expression.The standoff took place Wednesday in Union Square Park, after police forcibly dispersed an attempt by protesters a few days earlier to reoccupy Zuccotti Park, about three kilometers away, where the Occupy movement began last September.Sherman Jackson, an Occupy media representative, says confrontations with police over territory draw media focus away from the movement?s core message of corporate greed and income inequality. Jackson says he defers to those who support a physical presence, but thinks it is not necessary.?The fact is that we use social media, we use Twitter, we use Facebook, we e-mail, we text one another, and we can muster a couple of thousand people within an hour to gather at any spot that we ask them to gather at," said Jackson.Protester and saxophonist Dave Intrator says a physical presence is essential. He adds that the act of human beings assembling in a public space to talk politics, exchange ideas and to play music has become an exotic luxury.

Martin Greenfield knows a thing or two about suits. He’s been making them for over half a century at his shop in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn.During that time, Greenfield has measured and tailored suits for generals, members of Congress, Hollywood celebrities, and even U.S. presidents. His customers include Dwight Eisenhower, Bill Clinton, Barack Obama, and Donald Trump.But Greenfield did not arrive at his career in a usual way. He didn’t dream of growing up to sew clothes, or learn the business as an apprentice. Instead, Greenfield’s first encounter with a needle and thread happened when he was a prisoner at the Auschwitz concentration camp in 1944. He was 15 years old.?“While washing and scrubbing one of the Nazi’s uniforms, I ripped the collar of the shirt. The guard became angry and beat me with his baton. A nice man working in the laundry taught me how to sew a simple stitch,” says Greenfield.The kapo having no more use for the shirt, Greenfield kept the shirt for himself.“I eventually took the shirt and wore it all through the concentration camp, until I got to another camp (Buchenwald) and they made me take it off.”For Greenfield, the shirt had much value.“The day I first wore the shirt was the day I learned clothes possess power. Clothes don’t just ‘make the man,’ they can save the man. The kapos treated me a little better. Even some of the prisoners did the same. Wearing the shirt, the kapos didn't mess with me and they thought I was somebody."Greenfield’s parents and siblings were also at the concentration camp.

WASHINGTON - A suicide bomber targeted a group of Sikhs, an Afghan minority group, in Jalalabad city, the capital of eastern Nangarhar province, on Sunday, killing nearly 20 people.“They brutalized us. They have martyred 15 and wounded 15 other Sikhs. We are not aligned with any group or party. Why would anyone attack us? We never harmed anyone,” Tarlok Singh, a member of the Sikh religious minority, told VOA.However, an Afghan health official told VOA the death toll was higher, with 19 people killed — at least 17 from the Sikh community — and at least 20 others injured.The Sikhs reportedly were on their way to attend a gathering led by Afghan President Ashraf Ghani in the provincial governor's office when a suicide bomber on foot detonated his explosive device.Islamic State through its media wing, Amaq, took responsibility for the attack in Jalalabad city, however, the militant group claimed to have targeted a “medical compound.”It is believed to be one of the first times a suicide bomber has targeted members of the Sikh minority group in Afghanistan.WATCH: Video of the aftermath of the attackSorry, but your browser cannot support embedded video of this type, you can download this video to view it offline.“Unfortunately, it is the first time that our Sikhs become the victim of suicide bombing.

, ViolenceThe rate of teen pregnancy in Nigeria is a major public health issue and one of the most pressing global problems in the country today. According to the United Nation’s Children’s Fund (UNICEF), Nigeria’s National Population Bureau reported that of all the females aged 15 years old in Nigeria, 5,898 were adolescent-pregnant during 2008-11; which represented 6 percent of all female births in the country. A report released by the University of Jos has shown that over 60 per cent of the teenage pregnancies in the country are caused by unplanned pregnancies. This means that 60 per cent of those who become pregnant during early age are the poorest and most vulnerable.In this report entitled “The Unplanned Pregnancy Epidemic in Nigeria”, UNICEF Nigeria Country Representative (CR) Madam Jovita Ngozi says that in terms of access to family planning services, about 2 million of those who could benefit from those services do not receive them. The findings show that over the same period, there was about an 85 percent increase in the number of unplanned pregnancies in the country. Over 95 per cent of the unplanned pregnancies in the country during the same period involved the teenage aged population.More than half of all the teenagers in the country are from rural areas, especially from the western part of Nigeria. Although most of the urban children are educated and have access to contraceptives, these studies have shown that over two thirds of the rural girls (more than 60 per cent) and 90 per cent of the rural boys are uneducated. They cannot access the services they need and these may lead to unnecessary pregnancy. These girls may experience problems like infertility, loss of social status and physical disability or disability through such pregnancy. These problems are life threatening in the most vulnerable group in Nigeria and constitute a substantial health and human development burden.The report further revealed that some of these girls and boys may also face sexual abuse and violence during and after the pregnancy.

Government officials in Somalia's capital say a landmine blast has killed at least two civilians.The mine exploded Thursday in southern Mogadishu as a government convoy drove past.The city has been relatively quiet since the interim government declared victory over Islamist insurgents in late April. But earlier this week Monday, at least four police officers were wounded when their vehicle exploded in Mogadishu.Elsewhere in Somalia, an international aid organization said two of its workers have been kidnapped in a semi-autonomous province.A spokeswoman for the group CARE said the workers, one Kenyan and one British, have been missing since Wednesday in the northeastern region of Puntland.

TOKYO - Princess Mako, the granddaughter of Japan's emperor, is getting married to an ocean lover who can ski, play the violin and cook, according to public broadcaster NHK TV.The Imperial Household Agency declined to confirm the report Tuesday.Kei Komuro, the man who won the princess' heart, was a fellow student at International Christian University in Tokyo, where Mako, 25, also graduated, NHK said.They met at a restaurant in Tokyo's Shibuya about five years ago at a party to talk about studying abroad, and they have been dating several times a month recently, it said.Komuro has worked as "Prince of the Sea" to promote tourism to the beaches of Shonan in Kanagawa prefecture, the report said.Women can't succeed to the Chrysanthemum Throne in Japan.

Kenyan Police Guarding Campus During Annual Terrorism Awareness VigilStudents marked the 11th anniversary of the 2005 Kenya University bomb attack Monday with a series of vigils to commemorate the victims.In the first of several events, students gathered at the National University's main campus for a remembrance service at 1 p.m., before the university community heard a two-hour presentation by Kenya University faculty member Geoffrey Yikoh, who recounted the attack, and the aftermath of the attack and the university community's subsequent resolve to "fight for peace in Kenya."
